summary: The passage describes a row between Paul Merson and Andros Townsend over Merson's criticism of Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. Merson initially criticized Townsend for writing in his Sky Sports column that "if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody." Merson later apologized for his comments after Townsend scored a goal for England against Italy. The row between the two players seems to have passed, but Merson was unable to resist having another dig at Townsend after Tottenham drew at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer. Muto, who only graduated from Keio University a fortnight ago after completing an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves to west London. He has earned 11 caps for his country after signing his first professional contract in 2014, scoring once for the Samurai Blue.

The passage discusses a study that found a link between antibiotics given to babies in the first six months of life and increased likelihood of being overweight as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by killing gut bugs that would normally feed on food, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study did not prove causation, but the authors warn that antibiotic exposure in infancy may play a role in the childhood obesity epidemic and highlight the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, which was caught on camera. The guard lost his footing and dropped his rifle, causing embarrassment for himself and the tourists present. The incident occurred in front of hundreds of tourists who were watching the ceremony.

The passage discusses the upcoming remake of the miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had a massive audience. The new version will be produced by A&E Networks and will air in 2016. The remake will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family" and will include input from scholars in African and African-American history to ensure authenticity. The passage also notes that the new version will be shown on three networks simultaneously and will be co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original series.

A former royal footman has accused palace aides of attempting to force him into an orgy in the 1970s. The incident occurred when he was 27 and working at Clarence House, the Queen Mother's London residence. He was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff on his first day working there. The ordeal left him in tears and he left the job the same day. He finally decided to contact palace officials again last year after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s.

An Oregon couple announced they are expecting a child in a rap video they made set to the theme song from 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The clip, which features Jesse and Melissa Meek rapping as they drive in a car, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby.

The passage describes the sale of a dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind at auction for $137,000. The dress, which was originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over time. It was one of more than 150 items from the film that were part of a private collection of James Tumblin, who bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s. Other top selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, the trousers and jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. He suffered from minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The boy's leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the animals. The exhibit was closed following the child's fall. Cleveland Metroparks Zoo has plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, has been pointed at a house instead of enforcing the 30mph speed limit for motorists along the residential road. The camera has not been working for more than two years, and around 300 speed and traffic cameras using old technology were turned off across the region in March 2013. The camera could be removed completely, and there are no plans to include it in the new pilot.

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team. He is fit, healthy, and ready to run. Bolt has confirmed he will be part of Jamaica's team at the World Relays in the Bahamas. Bolt has a long and successful tradition in relays and always does his best to make the country proud. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

The passage describes how Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona's basketball team during a Euro League contest against Real Madrid. Neymar also played for Brazil in an international match against Chile, where he scored a goal and faced several challenges from the South American rivals. The passage mentions that Barcelona won their El Clasico contest against Real Madrid in La Liga, moving four points clear at the top of the table. Neymar and his teammates will return to La Liga on Sunday to face Celta Vigo as they compete for a treble of trophies.

The Italian coast guard has rescued over 8,480 migrants from Africa and the Middle East in recent days, with 20 boats in distress reported on Monday alone. However, there are fears that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea. The Italian coast guard has not confirmed the incident and has not found evidence of a migrant boat capsizing with 145 rescued. There has been a recent upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with an increase in rescues performed by the Italian Coast Guard to aid migrant boats.

The passage discusses Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's thoughts on the signing of Chilean forward Alexis Sanchez from Barcelona. Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, despite Liverpool's interest in him. Sanchez has made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes Sanchez is one of the best players around due to his qualities, efficiency, work rate, and fighting spirit. The passage also mentions the upcoming Barclays Premier League clash between Arsenal and Liverpool, with Wenger playing down any talk of a potential transfer move for Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He will attempt to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. Wiggins finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix 253.5km one-day race on Sunday. The current Hour record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February after the UCI, cycling's world governing body, reformed regulations, reigniting interest in the event.

Serena Williams beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off on Sunday, but the US team lost the match 3-2. Williams' doubles loss with Alison Riske against Errani and Flavia Pennetta meant the US was relegated to World Group II. Williams said the match was a "big eye opener" and that she needs to adjust her game to play better on clay courts. The US will need to work harder to get back to the World Group next year.

River Plate are interested in signing Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, who played for them previously. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Old Trafford, scoring just four goals in the Premier League. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian says the club dreams of Falcao's return and that the doors are open. Falcao has been in good form for Colombia recently, scoring three goals in two games to equal their all-time goalscoring record.

Ella Henderson, a pop star known for her impressive vocals, has joined forces with Batiste, a dry shampoo brand. She has been announced as the official face of the brand's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson with various hairstyles, including a glossy, wavy style and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership was created by the MILES agency, and the campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson expressed her excitement about working with the brand, stating that it is a product she uses regularly.

A billboard featuring the officer who shot Aaron Siler, a man killed by police, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, features a photo of Officer Pablo Torres and his dog, with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." Family and friends of Siler have called the billboard "disrespectful" and are asking for it to be taken down. The police association claims that no offense was intended and that the billboard was simply to thank the community for its support. The investigation into Siler's death continues.

The passage describes a clash between Iranian border guards and militants near the border with Pakistan, resulting in the deaths of eight Iranian border guards. Three of the militants were killed by Iranian forces, while the remaining survivors are being sought by Iranian officials. The militant group responsible for the attack is Jaish al Adal, which claims to be anti-Iranian and has targeted Shiites in Pakistan. The Pakistani government has condemned the attack and is investigating the incident.

The passage discusses the Japanese government's stance on encountering extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered any UFOs from outer space. The ASDF scrambles fighter jets if necessary and makes visual observations when detecting indications of an unidentified flying object that could violate the country's airspace. The passage also mentions former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who asked about aircraft being scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. Inoki claimed to have seen a UFO with his own eyes but admitted he didn't know personally if aliens existed. The passage notes that this wasn't the first time Japanese politicians have discussed the implications of visitors from another planet.

A passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China broke a toilet while squatting on it, resulting in deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He was hospitalized and received several dozen stitches. The passenger initially claimed he was sitting on the toilet but later changed his story to avoid paying compensation. The incident was deemed an accident by authorities.

A Pennsylvania man, Kevin Rebbie, 56, has been arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. Rebbie faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl found a hidden camera under the sink in a bathroom in March. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had purchased the camera specifically so he could record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered.

The passage describes a photographer named Yûki Aoyama who has created a series of images capturing po-faced teenagers next to their fathers who are leaping into the air. The images are from Aoyama's latest book, "Daughter and Salary Man," and feature fathers in sharp suits pulling energetic poses despite their age. The images have gained interest online due to their curious nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the upcoming start of the county championship season. It also mentions Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team after being controversially axed by Downton in 2014. Pietersen is seen posing for a team photo with his teammates, and it is mentioned that he will be playing for Surrey in the county championship season.

The passage describes the dismissal and subsequent reinstatement of Brazilian coach Ze Maria by Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt. Ze Maria was fired after a poor run, but was reinstated the next day by flamboyant owner Angelo Massone. However, Ze Maria was again fired after Ceahlaul were beaten 2-0 by mid-table FC Botosani. Ze Maria will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

The passage discusses Radamel Falcao's struggles with Manchester United during his season-long loan from Monaco. Despite scoring four goals, the club is unlikely to exercise their option to make the transfer permanent. Falcao's former teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his decision to leave Monaco for Manchester United and suggests he would have been better off staying at Monaco.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The man made off with the dairy's till and about $1500 in cash. Police are appealing for information to identify the suspect.

The passage describes the arrest of Kaitlyn Granado, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, on charges of having sex with two 15-year-old students. Granado was first arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with one of the students, and was released on bail. Now she has been arrested again after another student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January this year. According to the affidavit, the sexual relationship took place in her car late at night on January 18 and 19 across the road from another school in Dallas.

The passage describes a video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its mouth. The dog belonged to the owner of a local bike shop. The video has been viewed over half a million times online. The crocodile was seen holding onto the dog for hours, and the incident shocked the local community. The video has sparked reactions from social media users, some of whom found it disturbing.

Steve Bruce believes Hull City can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League this season. Despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, Bruce is optimistic that nine or eight wins could be enough to secure safety. Hull have six games remaining, including matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass.

The passage describes how a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the school's SATs results. The teacher, Ian Guffick, asked pupils to make changes to their national curriculum tests for 11-year-olds, which assess English, maths, and science. Despite the exam session finishing, Guffick altered a number of pupil's exam answers himself before the papers were sent off. The local education authority launched an investigation, which found that some pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions and that Guffick had done the same. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school last year. Guffick was later forced to give up his job at the school and had since admitted the allegations and accepted it amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. The Department for Education annulled the whole school's SAT's results after a probe by the local education authority.

The passage describes Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard's marriage to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, who is of Albanian descent. Lindegaard struggled for playing time at United, but he and Beqiri enjoy their time together off the pitch.

The passage describes an auction at Sotheby's where 13 glowing blue letters that once illuminated Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer. The letters, which had been hanging over the stadium since 1976, were expected to bring in anywhere from $300,000 to $600,000, but received no bids. The current owner of the signage is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium saw its final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, bought the letters 'on a lark' and joked that he might have gotten ahead of himself when he saw the size of the letters. In addition to the letters, Sotheby's was also auctioning off a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, which raked in a winning bid of $112,500 at auction.

The passage discusses Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminding Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after pictures emerged of them inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to Sterling and Ibe in his office on Thursday but neither will be disciplined. Rodgers wants to draw a line under the matter and is focused on steering Liverpool into their first FA Cup final of his reign.

The passage describes Mesut Ozil's return to Arsenal after the international break, where he scored two goals and provided two assists in a 2-0 win over Georgia. He is now preparing for a Premier League match against Liverpool.

The passage states that Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has denied reports that the club plans to replace Luis Enrique as manager. Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance and stated that the club is "very happy" with him. Enrique has only been in charge of the club since last summer and is six games away from winning the title. Despite speculation that Enrique will be replaced in the summer, Bartomeu said there is still time to discuss his contract. Enrique's side comfortably defeated Valencia on Saturday, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth around £100,000-a-week, which will run until the summer of 2020. This follows on from Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho agreeing contract extensions earlier this season. Henderson's form this season has been excellent, with 13 assists and seven goals from midfield. He is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season, but Liverpool's Chief Executive, Ian Ayre, expects him to stay at Anfield for 'a long time'.

The passage describes Filipe Luis' desire to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering bringing him back in the summer. Despite struggling to make the left back position his own at Stamford Bridge, Luis is happy at the club and wants to stay until the end of his contract. The passage also mentions that Luis played in Brazil's friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break, and that Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is refusing to let his league leaders rest on their laurels until the job is done. The defender's attention now turns to the Premier League having played for Brazil against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes' ban for accidentally knocking out George North has been overturned on appeal. Hughes was initially suspended for three matches after being deemed 'reckless' for failing to prevent his knee colliding with North's head during a try for Northampton. Hughes was shown a red card for the offense, but that dismissal has now been officially rescinded. The ban was overturned due to the lack of intent and the fact that the incident occurred accidentally. Hughes is now free to return to action immediately, but he is not in the match-day squad for Wasps' Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh tomorrow.

The passage describes how wildfires in Siberia caused a dramatic sunset in Seattle, with the smoke from the fires carrying across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. The smoke particles filter out shorter wavelengths of light, leaving only red and orange colors visible. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets will fade.

The passage describes how a woman named Becky Schoenig had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri. However, the car was later found by police and returned to her with some minor modifications, including red rims and detailing. Instead of being upset, Schoenig took to Facebook and posted a photo of her new ride, writing, "I want to thank the car thieves for pimping out my vehicle for me... This b**ch is pimpin now!!!" She also created a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who found her car and notified the police.

Manchester City players could miss out on £500,000 bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club's star players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, are on incentivised contracts to stay within financial fairplay requirements. The top three finishers in the Premier League qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round to join them. Manchester City is currently in fourth place and will be just four points ahead of main rivals Liverpool after defeat in the Manchester derby. The City squad has around £12 million resting on reaching their European target.

The Under 18s of Manchester United defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby', with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal with a free-kick. The match was played at Altrincham's home stadium, which has a capacity of 6,000. The United manager, Paul McGuinness, wanted to make the experience closer to what his players could expect if they made the step up to the seniors. The match was played in front of a crowd of close to 1,000, with entry being free. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand.

Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon's 147th cap for Italy. Hart, who passed his own milestone of 50 caps for England, said Buffon's experience and skill inspire him. Hart also expressed his desire to continue playing for both club and country and to accumulate more caps.

Chipotle has teamed up with Postmates to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The restaurant plans to add a nine per cent service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5 and up depending on distance and demand. The fast-casual chain is not the only franchise hoping to cash in on the delivery market, as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also planning to offer delivery services.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings are making an emotional plea to drop the death penalty for the man convicted in the case. They want the case to come to a close and for the defendant to spend the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all of his rights to appeal. They believe that the continued pursuit of that punishment could bring years of appeals and prolong reliving the most painful day of their lives.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747 that has been converted into a luxury home for a billionaire. The jet, which originally carried up to 600 passengers, now contains bedrooms, multiple lounges, and an onboard restaurant. The owner spent £400 million on the customization process, which took three years to complete. The jet features a large dining room, a lounge, a state room, and sleeping space in the "aeroloft" on the top deck. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with a conference room, executive suite, and a main suite that could be mistaken for a room in a top hotel. The jet is one of the most luxurious private planes ever built, and few people can ever imagine flying in such luxury.

The passage describes SpaceX's successful launch of an uncrewed cargo spacecraft called Dragon to the International Space Station. However, the company was unsuccessful in landing a rocket stage on a floating barge for the first time. SpaceX plans to continue trying to land rockets on the sea and eventually on the ground to reduce the cost of access to space. The smaller, top part of the rocket will carry the Dragon into orbit and then break away from the cargo ship and burn up in Earth's atmosphere. The Dragon will dock with the space station a couple of days after launch to deliver supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker.

The passage describes a contest launched by NBC's Today show to find an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding' at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winner will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the wedding, and the couple will be the first to marry at the chapel. The contest requires couples to submit a video or photos along with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

The passage discusses Liverpool's recent victory over Newcastle United in the Premier League, which has given them hope of catching Manchester City in the race for the Champions League. Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes that after finding winning form again following poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool can pile the pressure on to City who sit four points above them in the race for the Champions League. The passage also mentions that Henderson and Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of season in the 2-0 win over Newcastle United on Monday night, equalling the record for appearances by any player in the top five European leagues so far this campaign.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 at home in Serie A on Saturday, ending their four-month winless streak and moving four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal of the game in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several saves in the second half to secure the victory. Security was tight due to a fan of Napoli's death in a shooting incident before last season's Italian Cup final at the Stadio Olimpico. Roma's winless streak was extended to five matches, while Napoli's winless streak was extended to six matches.

The passage describes a lackluster season for Doncaster Rovers in League One, with an uninspired campaign resulting in mid-table mediocrity. The team's match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw, leaving the media team with a challenge to compile highlights for the club's YouTube channel. They opted for a brief highlight reel, consisting of just 27 seconds of footage, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle. The passage also mentions the managers on the touchline during the match.

The passage describes a man's unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, which he interacts with through touch. The fish initially resists the man's attempts to stroke it, but eventually becomes relaxed and enjoys the sensation. The man also feeds the fish frozen blood worms by hand and notices it becoming more sociable. The fish enjoys being stroked and becomes frustrated if not played with daily. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid and was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes' return to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs. Stokes has a fiery reputation and has shown his aggression in the past, but he needs careful management to control his aggression. The team wants to keep his natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents, but his aggression must be controlled. The coach, Peter Moores, had a long chat with Stokes after his clash with Marlon Samuels and gave him advice on how to respond. The team wants to have Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him hit his full potential.

The passage describes the upcoming Euro 2016 qualifier between Wales and Belgium, which has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Wales is in their best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup finals in Sweden. The game will take place at the Cardiff City Stadium, which is preferred by the Wales squad over the Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the scheduled date.

The England Under-17 team has been named for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. They are the defending champions and have qualified with a 100% record. They will face Italy in their opening match on May 7. The squad includes talented players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi of Arsenal, and Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold of Liverpool.

Manchester City are interested in signing Anderlecht's 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents to come out of Anderlecht's youth system. Patoulidis rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at the age of 12 due to his family's desire for him to continue his studies. Manchester City has had discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock in an attempt to agree on a compensation package for Patoulidis.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of a transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan, who was found strangled and beaten in a flat in Fulham, south west London. Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican national, died as a result of injuries to her head and neck. Police have not confirmed whether her profession as an escort was central to the investigation, but have appealed to anyone who may have had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan's body was found when London Ambulance Service was called to an address in Fulham, south west London.

The passage describes a woman named Dawn who had seven miscarriages and was saving money to buy a headstone for her child, Daniel James. Her friend, Jamie, stole the money and was caught lying about it during a lie detector test. Dawn was devastated and left the show in tears.

The Islamic State (IS) group has released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group, from captivity in northern Iraq. The majority of those released were women and children, while the rest were ill or elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders, according to a Peshmerga commander. The freed Yazidis were sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The motivation behind the release is unclear. The Yazidis have long suffered persecution, with many Muslims referring to them as devil worshipers. The Sunni Islamist militant group, ISIS, has been particularly cruel to the Yazidis, slaughtering them by the hundreds and raping and enslaving female captives. An international coalition responded by airdropping supplies and conducting airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

The passage describes how Harry Kane, a Tottenham Hotspur striker, has had an exceptional season both on and off the pitch. He has broken through into the first team and the England national team, and is now nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. The passage also mentions that Kane is featured in a clever new animation produced by Copa90, which showcases some of his best goals and celebrations from the season.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a season with no trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Rodgers' future at Anfield has been questioned after a third straight season without a trophy, but Carragher backed the Reds manager. Carragher said that Rodgers' job is to identify where in the team they need to improve and that the signings have to be right. Carragher received a Beacon Award at a ceremony in London on Tuesday night for his community work on Merseyside.

A four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport because it was deemed a security risk. The airport security officers demanded that James hand over his plastic nerf gun, which fires sponge darts, and performed a thorough patting down and inspection of the primary school child. The airport apologized for the inconvenience but pointed out that they had offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire. The airport defended their decision by stating that the safety and security of their passengers is their first priority and that all regulations on security are set by the government.

The passage describes a man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, who has posted an advertisement on Gumtree detailing his "requirements" for a girlfriend or wife. He seeks someone who loves pets, is non-drinking and non-smoking, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, and loyal, enjoys the outdoors, and is willing to receive benefits such as accommodation, a company car, phone, and laptop. The advertisement also outlines the man's personal details, including his athletic build, tattoos, and interests in traveling, sports, fishing, and camping. The man promises that all reasonable offers will be considered, and former partners need not apply.

The Football Association chairman, Greg Dyke, is proposing changes to the rules regarding the number of home-grown players in club squads and the definition of "home-grown." Five former England managers, including Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, have backed Dyke's call, warning that blocking the proposals could harm the English game and make it harder to win the World Cup. The current pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking, which is a clear disadvantage for any England manager. The rise of players like Harry Kane shows that England can still produce top young talent, but they need more opportunities.

The passage describes the birth of Demelza Poldark's baby daughter in the upcoming episode of the TV show "Poldark". The timeline of the pregnancy is questionable, as it jumps from Demelza talking about being eight months pregnant to giving birth in just a few minutes. The show has been criticized for its unrealistic portrayal of pregnancy.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performance and not worry about their relegation rivals during the final stretch of the season. The team is currently three points above the relegation zone after winning their last two matches, including a crucial 3-2 victory over West Bromwich Albion. Pearson emphasizes that the team's future is in their own hands and that they need to concentrate on their own games to give themselves a realistic chance of survival. He also cautions against getting too optimistic about other teams' performances, as they can only help if Leicester City does its own job.

The North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has completed the longest migration of a mammal ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This surpasses the previous record held by a humpback whale that swam a mere 10,190 miles. The study led by Bruce Mate, the lead author of the study, and the director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, suggests that some western gray whales may actually be eastern grays.

The passage discusses a study conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers that found children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to face police action and violence compared to better-off children who commit the same crimes. The study also identified gender as one of the most powerful predictors of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls on average to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The findings from the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, by the University of Edinburgh's School of Law, have been published in the latest edition of the Scottish Justice Matters journal.

Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear again in court next week. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. The passage also provides details about the events leading up to the stabbing, including the fact that Mr. Walsh and two other men entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee shortly after 01:00 on Sunday and called to houses in the estate looking for Mr. Haugh. During the altercation, Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back and was brought by ambulance to Limerick University Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene of Mr. Haugh's death, and a judge said the state had given evidence of tension in the area of Kilkee as a result of the killing and remanded Mr. Walsh in custody until 14 August.

The passage describes a tweet by Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan about Tom Elliott, who served in the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The tweet was deleted within an hour of being posted and an apology must be posted on Twitter before the end of Friday. The tweet was made after Elliott appeared on a BBC radio program in May 2014. The court was told that Mr. Elliott was alerted to the tweet by the victims' campaigner Ann Travers and by DUP assembly member Arlene Foster, who is to become Northern Ireland's first minister on Monday. The tweet was deleted by Mr. Flanagan within an hour of being posted. The apology, which must also be posted on Twitter before the end of Friday, will state that the Sinn Féin MLA accepts that his tweet about Mr. Elliott "was untrue and wholly without foundation". Mr. Justice Stevens has reserved judgement on the amount of compensation. The court was also told that the insurance firm which indemnifies MLAs at Stormont, has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in this case. The Sinn Féin MLA is challenging that decision in a separate court action

Hawick Knitwear, a company that employs over 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand. This increase in production is due to better-than-expected sales of the Hawick Knitwear-branded range, which launched in January. The company, which dates back to 1874, was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. The company has seen growth in its longer-established business of supplying customers who sell the garments under their private labels. The knitwear firm has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters each week, from about 7,500 last year, to keep up with demand.

The passage describes an incident where Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady, was struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, who claimed to have been blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now receiving treatment in residential care. Wright, who is married with three children, accepted responsibility for striking Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities. The exercise involves 10 warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, the U33, which is trying to avoid detection by the warships. The exercise is seen as a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines, which have increased their patrols in the area. The passage highlights the difficulty of locating an invisible enemy under vast stretches of ocean and the importance of anti-submarine warfare training. The exercise also serves as a reminder that some nations, including Britain, cannot do it alone and that the lack of any UK maritime patrol aircraft will have to be addressed in the government's forthcoming defense and security review.

The passage describes the ongoing conflict in South Sudan, which has led to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people, including 340,000 who have fled to neighboring Uganda. The violence is primarily ethnic-based, with the Dinka tribe targeting the Nuer and Equatorians. The conflict has resulted in widespread human rights abuses, including killings, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. The international community is urged to take action to stop the violence and provide assistance to the refugees.

The passage describes a professional boxing match between McKenzie and Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. McKenzie, who is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie, has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is being rebuilt as part of a £330m investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital was built in 1813 and has become cramped and outdated. The total cost of the project is £33m, with the remaining balance to be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014.

A man was shot and killed outside a property in Upperthorpe, close to the city centre, in Sheffield. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and taken to hospital, where he later died. The man was a member of a family who live close to the scene of the shooting, and relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred. The shooting is one of several that have taken place in Sheffield in recent weeks, although all the previous incidents have been in the north of the city and not close to the Upperthorpe area.

The passage describes the activities of various hacker groups, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, who use cyber warfare tactics such as DDoS attacks, hacking, and monitoring public CCTV systems to support or oppose political causes. The passage also mentions the use of hacked information to direct artillery fire and the targeting of rebel funding in electronic payment systems. The passage notes that the Ukrainian Cyber Troops have hacked into public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas of eastern Ukraine and Crimea to monitor troop movements and military hardware. The passage also mentions the hacking of several Ukrainian government websites by Cyber Berkut, which placed a message on their front pages reading "Joseph Biden is the fascists' master." The passage notes that the Ukrainian Cyber Troops have also hacked into public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas of eastern Ukraine and Crimea to monitor troop movements and military hardware.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of three Scottish politicians: Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond. Marwick sheds tears as McNeil bids farewell to the parliament, and again as Salmond tells the chamber that it's goodbye for now. All three are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Salmond uses his valedictory address to repeat a belief he expressed in his very first speech in the parliament that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse". He says that both the country and parliament are on a journey, and adds that "we are definitely stronger - so much stronger - as a result of that". He welcomes the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, but again insists that the bill does not fulfill the pledges which he said had been made by unionist politicians in the last days of the referendum campaign.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, will gather experiences of residential care from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The commissioner will review the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, focusing on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner's team will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The commissioner aims to ensure that those accountable for and running social care services understand the day-to-day realities of living in residential care in Wales and the action required to deliver the change needed to ensure that older people living in residential care have the best quality of life.

Harbro Group's pre-tax profit increased by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to the end of June 2016, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew over the year, both in Europe and in new markets further afield. The company manufactures and supplies feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors, and has a network of 19 shops across Scotland, operating under the Country Store brand. The outlook for agriculture is difficult to predict, but the industry is robust and the board is confident that the group will be well positioned for whatever business challenges Brexit may bring about.

A man in his 70s was found dead in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives want to question a 55-year-old man named Ian John McLoughlin, who is also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The investigation is still in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Anyone with information is urged to contact police or Crimestoppers.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its forecast for global growth to 3.4%, citing weak trade figures from China. This has implications for businesses and industries that rely on China's growth story.

The council leader announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July to allow feedback on the new vessel. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has faced several issues since its launch, including breakdowns, grounding, and damage to vehicles. The council is considering compensation for local businesses affected by the loss of trade.

A crash involving several vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville has been arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

The passage describes an international temp agency called Matching Models in London that has been criticized for its discriminatory hiring practices. The agency has advertised for personal assistants with specific physical characteristics, such as a "classic look" and "brown long hair with b-c cup," which has been deemed unlawful and demeaning to women. The Equality and Human Rights Commission has called for the agency to clarify its hiring practices, and women's equality campaigners have criticized the ads as being outdated. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends the practice by stating that looks are important to clients. The passage also mentions another job advertisement for a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche Cayenne for a Knightsbridge-based businessman and polo team owner. The employment lawyer, James Lynas, states that the advertisement is clearly unlawful and that anyone can complain to the Equality and Human Rights Commission. The passage concludes with a statement from the agency's website that emphasizes the importance of having the right people represent a company, but also acknowledges that first impressions are not everything.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to a private school in Bangalore, India. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school and shot two students, one of whom died. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is currently awaiting trial. This incident is rare in India, where gun crime at schools and colleges is uncommon.

The advocacy group Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017 and counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters has risen from seven to 16 this year. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks mostly to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his resignation ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished, and the MP has denied any wrongdoing. The loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council, when he was leader, to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, is now subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mr Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election, but in a statement, he said it was the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

The passage describes the shooting of Jordan Edwards, 15, by Roy Oliver, a police officer, in April 2018. Oliver was fired from his job for policy violations and faces charges of murder and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. The trial has not yet been scheduled. Oliver is currently free on bail. The passage also notes that this is the first time a police officer has been convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The passage discusses the decision of the incoming First Lady, Melania Trump, to keep her son, Barron, in his current school rather than move to the White House immediately after the inauguration. The passage notes that this is not unprecedented, as previous First Ladies have also chosen to keep their children in their current schools. The passage also notes that the role of First Lady is primarily ceremonial, and that the First Lady often uses her position to promote various causes and initiatives.
The man died in Inverness on 27 October this year. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been asked to scrutinise the initial police response to the man's call.

The passage describes a yellow warning of wind issued by the weather service, with gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) expected in certain areas, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction could add to the impact of the winds, causing disruption to travel on roads and at sea. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing one of the main routes into the town, and Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday to allow clean-up work to be carried out.

The Giants and Panthers played a hockey game where the Giants won 4-3. The Panthers scored first, but the Giants tied the game in the second period. The Giants then scored three more goals to win the game. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 points and Belfast with 25 points.

The Chinese Grand Prix was held in Shanghai, China on April 9, 2017. The race was won by Lewis Hamilton of Mercedes AMG Petronas, who started from the back of the grid due to a technical issue. He suffered a broken front wing on lap one and did five pit stops during the race. Despite this, he managed to finish in second place, just ahead of Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari. The race was marred by several incidents, including a collision between Kimi Raikkonen and Daniil Kvyat on the first lap, which caused both cars to retire from the race. The race was also notable for the use of the safety car, which was introduced on lap four after a number of collisions on the first lap. Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit newspaper. He is the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality, and his former teammates praised his announcement. There was also support for Hitzlsperger from leading figures in German football administration. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which like England has struggled with the problem of homophobia in football.

The passage describes how Sidwell, a midfielder for Brighton, has helped the team achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at the end of the season, Sidwell is hoping to sign a new deal to continue playing for the team. The team is currently in the lead for the league title and is hoping to secure it in the final two matches. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League with several teams and believes he deserves the opportunity to play at the top level again.

The Seasiders scored after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso delivered a pinpoint chip into the area, where Jamille Matt turned the ball home from three yards. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe denied Matthew Briggs with a sensational save to push the ball behind after 17 minutes, but the visitors did equalise from the resulting corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Colchester failed to re-take the lead on the stroke of half-time as Slocombe produced a brilliant save from George Elokobi's close-range effort, before Guthrie headed against the bar from two yards. Blackpool should have clinched the win 15 minutes from time, as Tom Aldred was found unmarked from a corner, but he headed wide from eight yards. Colchester finished the game with 10 men, after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The passage describes a 29-year-old football player who made 37 appearances for Coventry City last season before being relegated from League One. He has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. The player could make his debut for Colchester United in their upcoming EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. The team started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum to honor and commemorate the police service and those who have lost their lives in the line of duty. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff and will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of the officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The memorial will be completed by 2019 and will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers, with the names of loved ones as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial.

Manchester United won 1-0 at Sunderland, remaining 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left. The team is focused on winning their next game, the derby against Manchester City. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained at Sunderland. The team has won 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK and the debate surrounding corporate tax avoidance. Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated that the company pays the taxes that are legally required and that it is up to the government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more taxes. Schmidt also expressed his belief that taxes are not optional and that companies should pay the taxes that are legally required. The head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, Margaret Hodge, suggested that a new committee should be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, and Google, along with other multinationals, has been criticized for organizing their tax affairs in ways that minimize the amounts they pay in the UK. European Union leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities" to monitor the situation.

The NHS has been struggling to reduce its agency bill, which reached £3.6bn last year. The regulator, NHS Improvement, wants to bring this down by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October to limit the amount hospitals can pay for agency staff, with the aim of reducing the overall cost and reducing reliance on agency staff. The progress being made is promising, but the NHS is still short of its target. The figures released by NHS Improvement do not cover NHS "bank" staff or money spent getting employed staff to do overtime. The regulator will start publishing "league tables" of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending later this year.

The passage describes the decline of the Longford Town Centre in Ireland due to the economic crash, but local traders believe there is a turnaround. The government is investing in water meters and broadband, but the opposition party argues that the money should be spent on other initiatives. The Center Parcs tourism development in County Longford is expected to create jobs, but it still needs planning permission. Local traders want free parking to attract more customers.

The passage describes a cricket tournament with eight teams competing against each other twice. The top four teams qualify for the play-offs. The tournament finishes on 29 May in the same stadium. The leading run-scorers are Warner, Kohli, and De Villiers, while the most sixes are scored by Warner, De Villiers, and Kohli. The highest score in an innings is 108 by De Kock, 90 by Warner, and 90 by Gambhir. The most wickets are taken by McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman. Four current or former England players will participate in the tournament. The fixtures and results are provided for the duration of the tournament.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013. Many of these bags cannot be recycled and are often thrown away after use, causing environmental problems such as pollution of rivers and rubbish dumps. In an effort to reduce the number of bags being thrown away, people in England will now have to pay 5p for each plastic bag starting from October. This is expected to encourage people to reuse the bags they already have. Campaigners hope that this measure will help to reduce the amount of plastic waste being produced and improve the environment.

The passage describes a severe storm that caused damage to a school roof in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, and power cuts for hundreds of homes across Wales. The storm also caused train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts for hundreds of homes. The storm followed a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales, which was in force until midnight on Friday. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six of its fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to "adverse weather conditions" on the Irish Sea, transferring passengers to their cruise ferry services. Arriva Trains Wales warned of "speed restrictions and possible delays" for all services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead due to the winds. The National Trust also closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, with earlier restrictions on both the A55 Britannia Bridge in north Wales and the M48 Severn Bridge in Monmouthshire lifted. However, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has seen at least one festive event postponed - Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in

The passage describes a new movie project that will reunite Jordan with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. Jordan is excited about the project and is looking forward to working with Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther will be released in February 2018.

The passage describes the renovation and refurbishment of Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios, with the goal of transforming the east wing into a cultural destination. The theatre, founded in 1875, will be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The project is being funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust. The theatre and studios are part of a larger restoration project that will cost £26.6m. The theatre is expected to reopen in 2018.

The passage describes the career of Jack Milner, a former Manchester City player who has won 61 caps for England. He was a member of the English squad at two World Cups and two European Championships, but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

The passage describes how Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador caught fire, destroying the house and killing the family's pets. The fire was caused by rubbish being burned in the wood stove, and the family was able to escape with only their pyjamas on. The community has since rallied around the family, donating clothes, shoes, and even a bike for the family's son.

The energy drinks giant is considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club. Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m. They now own more than 85% of the club. West Ham have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium in August. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but intends for the ownership to pass on to his children.

The passage describes the winners of the MTV Movie Awards, including The Fault in Our Stars winning best movie, Shailene Woodley winning best female performance and best kiss, Bradley Cooper winning best male performance, Channing Tatum winning best comedic performance, and Meryl Streep winning best villain. Other winners include Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. The ceremony also featured a look ahead to upcoming summer releases and jokes about actor Kevin Hart's size.
The Dons loaned Smith to United in July and he has five goals this season. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie side.

The Northumberland County Council has stated that the weather is suitable for their Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes. The council aims to fill in 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be employed to repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters caused by heavy rain.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland in December 2016, where rigging supervisor Steve Innes and his colleagues discovered they had been exposed to alpha radiation. The company took additional precautionary steps, and Wood Group, the contractor, stated its commitment to employee safety. Innes, who has struggled to find work since raising concerns, claims that the workers now face cancer fears and that EnQuest failed in its duty of care. The men were working on shutdown work with pipe equipment, and Innes said they were told there was a problem two-thirds of the way through the trip. They were told a reading had been taken the night before, and all the work was stopped. Innes said they had been exposed to radioactive material for hours at a time and that the levels of radiation may not cause them long-term harm, but he was continuing to undergo tests.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a stolen Indian antiquity, a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari, for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The company's manager later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture. The sculpture was thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu in southern India. The decision to return the item came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government body looking after its antiquities, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. The museum will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck near Lucca, Italy, causing minor damage and no reported injuries. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence. Several aftershocks followed, and phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the affected area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. The earthquake was described as a classic event for the region, with medium strength and shallow depth. Italy has a history of earthquakes, including a deadly one in L'Aquila in 2009 that killed almost 300 people.

The passage describes a fruit that is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. It also mentions Austin Grant from Sheffield who had been dubious about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate, but has finally seen some results.

The passage announces that the release of the open world adventure game has been delayed until 24 March due to additional testing and polishing needed to make it as good as possible. The company also announced that eagerly-awaited online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release date. The PC version of GTA V will be visible in 1080p at 60fps, with up to 4K resolution and support for up to triple monitor configurations. The minimum specifications required to run GTA V have also been published.

The passage describes the 76-year-old artist who won the Â£25,000 prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The artist, who has also made the prize longlist on three other occasions, said finally winning was "very nice indeed". The work depicts a leper squint, which Simpson said were "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part". The relatively small size of Squint (19) - which is about 7ft (2.1m) in height - was one of the reasons Simpson entered it into the competition, though he also admitted that it "seemed to be a good idea to send one that I was conversant with and was working with". The prize money will be spent on "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints".

The Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit newspapers' offices were attacked by masked assailants who shot at the buildings, causing shattered windows and numerous spent bullet casings. The attacks occurred simultaneously, with no casualties reported. The two papers support the AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The police have cordoned off the area and are searching for the attackers.

The passage describes the signing of a 24-year-old player by the Mariners, who have agreed to bring him in on a free transfer after he spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley. The player has previously played for Burton and will officially join the Mariners on January 1st. This is Bignot's first signing for the team.

The passage discusses the potential appointment of Southgate as the new manager of the English national football team. It also mentions Wenger's contract situation and his thoughts on Southgate's suitability for the job. Additionally, it covers Wenger's comments on Bellerin's contract negotiations and Ramsey's injury.

The passage describes an incident where a local man fell from a cherry picker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road at 13:45 GMT on Thursday. The incident is being investigated jointly by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive. The company involved is cooperating fully with the investigation.

The Transport Minister announced a new charter arrangement for freight vessels serving the Northern Isles that will end the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had claimed that some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck, which is contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink said it had repeatedly offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined to accept. The new arrangements will come into force early next month subject to some financial and regulatory details being finalised.

The passage describes the death of Ken Dickie, 64, who died in hospital six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, had admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. The trial heard that Mrs Mitchell and Mr Dickie had been in a relationship for several years and were going through a "down phase" when Mr Mitchell visited his mother at the park on 7 May. In the evening, Mr Mitchell accompanied his mother and Mr Dickie to the holiday park bar and got "tanked up" on alcohol. The two men had a confrontation outside and were separated by members of the public. Mr Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. He and his mother Samantha, 57, also of Apple Close, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the course of events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, has passed away at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton's songs, including "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Boogie Nights," have become iconic hits for various artists. He was known for his low profile and was nicknamed "The Invisible Man." Temperton's songwriting ability was influenced by his father's use of a transistor radio in his crib. He worked with Quincy Jones and wrote songs for Michael Jackson's albums "Off The Wall" and "Thriller." Temperton won a Grammy Award for his work on "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars for his work on the soundtrack for "The Color Purple."

Swansea University researchers have discovered ancient earthworks in Brazil's Amazon rainforest, possibly dating back 2,000 years. The team, which includes researchers from Exeter and Reading universities and Brazil's São Paulo and Belém universities, found more than 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The function of these mysterious sites is still little understood, but it is thought they were used sporadically as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America or Britain's Stonehenge. The team analyzed soil samples, phytoliths, charcoal quantities, and carbon stable isotopes to reconstruct ancient vegetation and assess the amount of ancient forest burning. The research suggests that the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation, unlike the towering Maya pyramids of Central America, and raises questions about their purpose. The new research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans.
