The Australian tennis player, ranked 12th in the world, beat world number 29 Querrey in 53 minutes to progress to the second round. He won the Japan Open on Sunday and is closing in on the top 10. He said his success in Japan and the travelling involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium had taken its toll. He didn't have the greatest sleep last night and got in late the day before. The ride to the courts wasn't great either.

The passage discusses the human papilloma virus (HPV) jab and its potential benefits in protecting against head and neck cancers. It mentions that the vaccine is currently only available for girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision on whether to roll out the vaccine for boys. Charities and organizations are calling for the vaccine to be made available to boys as well.

The passage describes the tragic story of Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy who died from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Despite his illness, Jak remained positive and shared updates about his journey on social media. He attended a school prom in his honor, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

The passage describes a soccer match between Egypt and Uganda, which ended with Egypt winning 1-0. The game was relatively dull with few chances for either side, but Egypt's Mohamed Salah teed up El Said, who scored the only goal of the game on 89 minutes. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the game. The win means that Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday for top spot of Group D, while Uganda are out of their first tournament since 1978.

The Lancashire County Council has decided to use land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new rail station. The decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail of all three sites. The council hopes that Skelmersdale could get two direct trains to Liverpool per hour under the plans it has made in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred location is big enough to allow for future expansion and has good highway access and good connectivity to the town and the surrounding area. The authority confirmed it will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land.
The plants were discovered during a police search of a warehouse in Ashbourne on Saturday morning. They were found in an elaborate grow house and a man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A woman in Hamelin, Germany, was dragged by her neck through several streets and found with serious injuries. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, has been arrested and is in custody. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is still unclear.

The research found that women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The study, conducted by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, compared 4,600 workers and found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found that there was no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey and found that differences in negotiating behavior existed between younger and older workers.

The passage describes the Oxford City Council's efforts to find a new burial site for the city. Despite conducting ground investigations and surveys at various potential sites, the council has not found any suitable locations. Two existing cemeteries will soon be full, and the council is still exploring other options. The council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but has run out of suitable land within the city. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19-22 July will offer visitors an augmented reality app to access online information about the festival. This includes videos and band interviews that can be viewed on phones and tablets. The festival features acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, says the augmented reality experience is an extra feature to enhance the festival experience for visitors and allow people around the world to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere.

An Irish-bred horse died after winning a race at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but had never collapsed before. The trainer described the horse as the "horse of a lifetime".

A 15-year-old girl was raped by a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The defendant, now 34 and named Davina, denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4th. The judge remanded her into custody and said she would likely be held at a male prison in Winchester. The court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted to commit suicide last summer. Protocols have been put in place for her detention at the prison. The victim said she shouted and swore at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends had not woken up. She had only drunk a can and a half of Foster's and clearly recollected the events. The court heard that in 2014 Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic lost to American Sam Querrey in the third round at Wimbledon in July. He won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The passage describes a chainsaw carving competition with more than 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US. The competitors will use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will be returning to defend his title and keep the Claymore Trophy.

The passage describes the return of rugby player Dan Webb, who has been out due to a foot injury. He is close to returning and plans to get fit before the Six Nations tournament in February. He has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union and turned down offers from elsewhere to stay at the region.

Two men were caught trying to smuggle 58lb of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One of them fired at the agents before running away. The other man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested. A Canadian citizen, Nathan Hall, was also arrested after being found with a backpack containing ecstasy. A woman and her boyfriend were arrested for their roles in the smuggling operation.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen an increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with around 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The total number of children suffering from online abuse is thought to be far higher, with some as young as seven reporting being bullied, abused, and scared to go to school. Online trolls are causing misery and humiliation for thousands of children. The charity's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, says the figures should be a wake-up call and that bullying can wreck young people's lives, especially when it continues beyond the school gates. Cyber-bullying can follow children home until it becomes a persecution they cannot escape. Schools must take the problem seriously, and children must ask for help. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance.

The US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. This decision infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the US of helping draft the language of the resolution and pushing for its passage. The resolution stated that the establishment of settlements has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law. Israel rejected the resolution, and the BBC reported that it was particularly angry about the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had indicated it would press ahead with a planned vote on authorising 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but on Wednesday, the vote was postponed at the request of the prime minister's office.

The passage describes the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, including a tribute from Prince William, a picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George released for stamps, and events such as a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, a ceremony to open a new bandstand, and a visit to Alexandra Gardens. The passage also mentions the Queen's upcoming birthday celebrations, including a walk around Windsor and the lighting of a beacon.

The passage describes a football match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United in the EFL Cup. West Ham United won the match 2-0, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. The match was a bright start for West Ham United after they had lost their previous two matches in the Premier League. Cheltenham Town, who were unchanged from their previous match, did not manage to test West Ham United goalkeeper Adrian. The match ended with Cheltenham Town's exit from the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a hospital radiographer, died in a car crash caused by Andreas Werner, who failed to see McNicholl as he turned his car. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be sent to jail, saying it was a momentary lapse and nothing would bring McNicholl back.

Imran Khawaja, a British fighter in Syria, is facing a possible prison term up to life imprisonment for his role in the conflict. He was involved in fundraising, video diaries, and tours of fighters' quarters for the group Rayat al Tawheed, which is affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was involved in appeals for donations and was seen in videos and pictures of his personal jihad. He was considered so dangerous that while he was on remand, he was held in the special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison.

The passage describes Jackson, a 22-year-old soccer player who scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, finishing eighth in the table. He has signed with Barnsley for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Jackson's speed and ability to get past defenders make him a good fit for Barnsley's playing style, according to caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season. The passage also mentions that the latest football transfers can be found on a dedicated page.

The passage describes the arrival of bottles at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard, which are believed to have come from a container ship that lost a container during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The bottles are sealed, but some have leaked. The National Trust volunteers have been clearing them away as they pose a risk to wildlife. Conservationists are concerned about the impact on sensitive marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has stated that there is no currently available evidence that the bottles washed up on the Cornish coast are from the lost container. The National Trust believes that the container went overboard from a ship during stormy seas. Cornwall Council and its partners will be monitoring beaches in the area.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00, resulting in several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

The passage is about Dervite, a French centre-back who played for Bolton Wanderers last season and helped them secure promotion to the Championship. He has made 83 appearances in all competitions since joining Bolton from Charlton in 2014. The manager, Phil Parkinson, praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is one of several players who have signed new contracts with Bolton following their promotion.

The passage describes the cooperation between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour Party in the UK Parliament to oppose government amendments related to EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, this cooperation ended when MPs rejected the amendments, with the Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. The passage also highlights the history of cooperation between the two parties on various issues, but notes that there may be residual tensions going forward.

The passage discusses the lack of emphasis on defense in the upcoming election, despite the increasing instability of the world. The UK has been cutting its armed forces, and the country's defense spending has fallen to sixth place globally. The next government is likely to face difficult decisions regarding defense, and the military is concerned about future cuts. The UK's nuclear deterrent is a contentious issue, with some parties wanting to reduce or eliminate it. The country's two new aircraft carriers are also a concern, as they may not be fully manned and equipped.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The club has made a complimentary tax declaration of £13.55m to cover eventual interpretations of the contracts drawn up in the operation to sign Neymar. The club denies the existence of any tax-related crime in relation to the fiscal obligations arising from the signing of the player. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season, as well as netting three in seven Champions League matches.

The passage describes the tragic death of Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, who was killed in a head-on collision with a car being driven by an elderly man who had died. The family of Mr. Luciw, who was the father of a baby girl, called for regular driving tests for older people to prevent similar accidents. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated that there is no plan to restrict licensing based on age, but older drivers must renew their licenses every three years and report any medical conditions that may affect their driving.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the use of transvaginal mesh implants to treat pelvic organ prolapse and incontinence. Many women have reported debilitating side effects from the implants, leading to protests and calls for an independent review. The review, led by Professor Alison Britton, concluded that the implants should not be offered routinely and recommended that patients be given a range of treatment options and information to make informed choices. The report also called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for an all-out ban, the Scottish government stated that it does not have the power to do so. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report.

The passage describes how Muir broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan had earlier raised concerns about whether Muir's race had met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts. However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official.

The passage describes the results of the equestrian event at the Rio Olympics, where Jung won gold, Astier Nicolas won silver, and Phillip Dutton won bronze. William Fox-Pitt, who was in an induced coma after a fall, finished 12th. The passage also mentions the opportunity to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

Andy Murray defeated Fognini in four sets to reach the last 16 of the US Open. Murray won 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 after two hours and 39 minutes. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari of Greece.

The passage describes a incident where paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived a short time later and found several people still at the bar. Till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, of Kevin Lynch Park in the town, was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. James Thomas, 44, of the same address, faced one count of the same charge. The judge said Ms O'Neill, who is the license holder, had "an appalling record" and expressed concern that he did not have power to impose a custodial sentence.

The Ulster Unionists want the election to be a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled. However, the focus has now turned on them following Mike Nesbitt's comments that domination doesn't work, partnership does. Danny Kennedy, a senior party colleague, publicly distanced himself from the remarks, but Nesbitt said it was reaffirming to know he was listening. Nesbitt denied having any regrets or making a mistake and said he wouldn't withdraw a word of what he had said. The party's manifesto, entitled 'Real Partnership', includes calls for action in tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, and guaranteeing that no group is worse off because of Brexit. The party also calls for cleaning up Stormont.

The Justice Minister in Northern Ireland has confirmed that a motion will be put forward to the assembly for approval, which will bring the region into line with England and Wales by introducing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses. This proposal, known as "Turing's Law" after the World War II code-breaker Alan Turing, would allow both posthumous and living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons. The motion is expected to be passed by the assembly and will be implemented as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland.

The passage describes Laura Muir's performance in the 1500m race, where she finished second behind Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12. This time broke Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60 and moved Muir to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir expressed her excitement about breaking the Scottish record and hopes to secure an Olympic place for Great Britain in the upcoming British trials in Birmingham.
The passage provides a list of Scotland's "most excellent" beaches based on water quality.

The passage discusses the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006 by two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. The UK government believes the Russian state was involved in the murder, but the suspects deny any wrongdoing. The passage also mentions the risks to the public from polonium radiation and the failure to extradite the suspects to the UK for trial.

The passage describes the appointment of Steve Smith as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing the retiring Michael Clarke. Smith, who already leads the one-day side, will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. Fellow batsman David Warner has been named as Smith's vice-captain. The passage also notes that Smith has played in 32 Tests for his country, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66.

The passage describes the stance of a politician named Mr. Farron on LGBT rights and equality. He stated his passion for LGBT rights and his intention to defend equal marriage and extend marital rights to transgender individuals. He also mentioned his refusal to answer questions about whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, citing his belief that everyone is a sinner. He explained his vote against the Equality Bill in 2007, stating his support for equality and his commitment to defending the law on equal marriage and extending it to other areas. He also discussed the issue of the spousal veto for transgender individuals and his support for equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare is planning to use the plant for its pharmaceutical production, with the hope that many of the jobs will be filled by ex-Sanofi staff. Accord Healthcare is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, developing, manufacturing, and distributing more than 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland would be leaving the council. Ellis was the interim director of corporate governance and had been acting as deputy chief executive for several months. Monaghan was the head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland was the head of human resources and customer services. The leader of the opposition SNP group, Stephen Flynn, criticized the council's inability to retain senior staff and predicted more departures. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin told MCN that he was quitting road racing but he later clarified his position on Facebook. He will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the People's Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll last month. The PDP lost control of key northern states such as Katsina and Kaduna, and also lost control of Adamawa, one of the states affected by the militant Islamist group Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which will be of huge concern to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence due to stiff rivalry, and the battle for power and money. Ethnic differences also fueled the conflict in some areas

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Olam and Temasek deny the allegations, stating that they have strict sourcing policies and are committed to sustainable practices. The passage also mentions concerns about the palm oil industry's troubled track record, including accusations of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and the burning of plantations.
The restaurant started serving puppy platters due to a new law that allows dogs to eat at restaurants as long as they are outdoors.

The passage discusses the status of three players for Derby County: Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury and has only played from the bench in the last two games; Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late goal against Huddersfield; and Derby County striker David Nugent could return after missing the previous game due to a groin injury.

The ban on YouTube in Pakistan has been lifted as Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The ban was imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the US-made film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. The ban has been lifted as Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform.

The passage describes the controversy surrounding the FIFA presidential election, where Domenico Scala, head of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, was barred from participating due to a conflict of interest with a candidate. The article also discusses the upcoming election and the candidates vying for the position.

Two men, Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road. They were believed to be working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been carried out at the company, which makes buckets for diggers. Evidence gathered so far suggests there was a flashover explosion, which occurs when there is a build-up of toxic fumes and some sort of ignition. The Health and Safety Executive said its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence.

The passage describes how Tunisia and Morocco were both initially excluded from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to disputes with the Confederation of African Football (CAF). Tunisia was excluded after lodging complaints against CAF during the 2017 Nations Cup, while Morocco was excluded after refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to concerns about importing the Ebola virus. Both countries were later allowed to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup after their disputes with CAF were resolved. The passage also mentions that Tunisia and Morocco are both preparing for a future full of good things for Africa and Morocco, respectively.

The passage describes a mass fracas during a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, resulting in the sending off of two players from each team. Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off for violent conduct, while Cesc Fabregas was not disciplined further. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal of the season, while Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. The clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The hosts won with a day to spare at Old Trafford to level the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. England's coach Trevor Bayliss said that Root went away and did a bit of soul-searching and hard work, came back and did exactly what he said he was going to do.

The British and Irish Lions have named interim coach Rob Howley as part of their backroom team, with forwards coach McBryde assuming head coach responsibilities for the third time. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. The involvement of Welsh coaches is believed to benefit the national team.

Hull City beat Southampton 2-1 in a Premier League match, ending a six-game losing streak. The win was Hull's first in the league since 20 August. Southampton's Charlie Austin scored a sixth-minute penalty, but Hull's Robert Snodgrass scored a goal and an assist in the second half. Hull's Abel Hernandez and Will Keane were injured in the first half, but Snodgrass returned to the pitch and helped lift the team's spirits. Hull City boss Mike Phelan praised his players for their performance, despite the loss of two strikers. Southampton manager Claude Puel acknowledged his team's mistakes and said they need to learn from them. The match ended with Hull City leading 2-1.

A motorcyclist died in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at about 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist lived locally, but no further details have been released. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses to the collision to come forward.

The passage describes the cancellation of an investigation into claims of abuse of power in Macedonia, which was condemned by both the opposition and EU officials. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder.

Swansea City have appointed assistant manager Paul Clement as their new manager after sacking Bob Bradley. The club wants to appoint a new boss as soon as possible, with Clement being the first choice. The club is concerned about the possibility of relegation and the difficulty of getting back up if they do go down. Swansea City were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and have struggled since then, with the departure of key managers such as Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup. The current squad is believed to be good enough to stay up, but the club is reminding new signings of its history and the importance of staying up.

The Daggers, who reached League One in 2010, needed victory to keep their slim survival hopes alive. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave them hope after Jay Simpson fired the O's into a 2-0 lead. But Armand Gnanduillet fired in the winner to relegate Dagenham and keep Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham reached the Football League for the first time in their history in 2007, but they now return to the National League under John Still, the same manager who took the club from the Conference to League One. The Daggers have League Two's worst goal difference, and have conceded 20 goals more this season than they had at this point last term. Still's side have also struggled in attack, with 40-year-old striker Jamie Cureton netting nine goals, compared to the 20 he scored as Dagenham finished 14th in the 2014-15 campaign. Boss Still, who returned for his third spell at the club in December, told BBC Radio London on Wednesday that he is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season.

The passage describes Steven Gerrard's return to his former club Liverpool as a youth coach in February. It mentions that he had a good chat with the club and that he wants to be a manager in the future. The passage also notes that Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left the club in 2015 after winning several titles. He retired from playing in November after a 19-year career.

The passage describes a football match between Morton and Alloa. McManus scored for Morton on the quarter-hour mark, and Ross Forbes' deflected strike doubled their lead. Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back into the game with a shot before half-time. However, Morton continued to dominate, with McManus scoring again and Denny Johnstone adding to the score late on, ensuring a comfortable win for the hosts.

The passage describes how Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now closed. The owners of these places are being investigated under suspicion of running an illegal school. Ministers are also consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors whose job will be to investigate illegal schools.

The passage describes the opening of a gin distillery at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scotland. The lead distiller, Kate Macinnes, discusses the potential for the Scottish Borders to become a region of distilling excellence and the use of local botanicals in the gin production. The gin is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, 51, of Bradburn Road, Wakefield, reversed the vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013. Green must have consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks.

The passage describes the lifting of Luis Suarez's ban from playing organized matches, allowing him to train and play in friendly matches. The ban still applies to competitive international games and his competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be against Real Madrid in El Clasico. The passage also discusses the reasons behind the ban and the appeal process.

The passage describes a race where competitors must tackle a 380-metre course, including hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. Competitors can be married or not, and the race saw all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and one woman carrying a woman. The winners, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna, will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the upcoming change from paper to electronic car tax discs, which will lead to changes in job roles and potentially job losses at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). The minister reassured employees that any reductions in staff numbers will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business.

The passage describes the Hungarian government's stance on EU interference in its domestic issues, particularly regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. The government has received support from Poland to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU objects to Hungary's policies, but the government maintains that these issues fall under national competence and should not be interfered with by the EU. The passage also mentions the Hungarian government's controversial Higher Education Law, which could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University, founded by philanthropist George Soros.

The passage describes the casting of actors for the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, including Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Other notable actors joining the cast include Kevin Kline as Maurice and Josh Gad as LeFou. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The columnist, Adrian Gill, has been diagnosed with multiple types of cancer, including a "meaty malignancy". Despite his illness, he has been described as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the Sunday Times, where he worked for 30 years. Gill's final column, discussing his diagnosis, will be featured in tomorrow's Sunday Times. Gill's writing was known for its wit, intelligence, and fearlessness, and he was celebrated for his ability to write compelling stories despite his dyslexia. However, his writing often caused controversy, and he was once thrown out of a Gordon Ramsay restaurant along with actress Joan Collins. Gill was born in Edinburgh in 1954 and attended St Christopher School in Letchworth Garden City, Hertfordshire. He studied at the Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design and the Slade School of Fine Art in London. Gill's illness prompted his engagement to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he also had two children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat in Ulan Bator. The diplomat was accused of hitting Sukhbaatar over the head with a bottle and kicking him in the face. Sukhbaatar's father stated that his son spent about 10 days in a coma after the beating. The swastika, which is associated with the Nazis, is a traditional symbol in Mongolia that predates Hitler. The Russian embassy called local press reports "distorted" and said it was investigating the incident. The suspect in the beating has not been identified, and the case is currently under investigation.

Action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration against Heathrow Airport's expansion plans on Monday. The protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of the aerodrome. They will appear in court on 19 August. The protest took place on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. The Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

The passage describes a cricket match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire. Nick Selman scored a century for Glamorgan, while Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took several wickets for Gloucestershire. The match ended with Glamorgan winning by 101 runs.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday. He will be sentenced next week. Hughes said he was planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, prosecutors said while outlining the case earlier in the proceedings. He said he would then shoot them on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry, who was told the defendant had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009, remanded him in custody pending sentence. During a previous hearing, Hughes's legal team said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers. The court heard at the time, North Wales Police was particularly concerned because the defendant was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

Yorkshire posted a score of 255-7 against Surrey, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a stand of 130. However, a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker undermined Yorkshire's run-chase. Tim Bresnan made 68, but Yorkshire were all out for 236. Yorkshire were hoping to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, but lost to Durham in the T20 Blast semi-finals last weekend. Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment at not being good enough when it mattered.

A 56ft converted trawler was in distress 6 miles west of South Stack. The crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST and reported that the pump on board was unable to cope with the water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

The passage describes a middle-distance runner who will miss the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She plans to focus on her studies and potentially compete in the World Indoor Championships in March.

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles in the current season, including their lack of goals, defensive issues, and the departure of key players. The author, Robbie Savage, predicts that Liverpool will struggle to compete with Chelsea and suggests that Brendan Rodgers needs to improve his team's performance to avoid a repeat of last season's disappointment.

The Â£45m facility in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus in honor of the late William McIlvanney, a renowned writer who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was passionate about providing good education for young people and became an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University. He later changed careers to write full-time and gained immediate recognition with the publication of his first novel, Remedy Is None. McIlvanney is known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" and wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works such as Docherty and The Big Man. He was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster, and contributed to political and sporting life in Scotland through a series of columns and TV programmes.

The town near the swimming pool was evacuated due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s. An exclusion zone remains in force on the river while experts make safe the sea mine. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. There was also an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services, affecting sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community of Gourock.

The passage discusses the cuts in funding for various sports in the UK, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton. Cycling, which won 12 medals in Rio, had its funding cut by over £4 million. The government has set targets for Team GB to win between 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed. Judo, which also won a bronze medal, had its funding increased slightly. The cuts were made because UK Sport needs to prioritize investments to protect and enhance medal potential.

The passage describes a proposed development in Bournemouth's East Cliff area that includes a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage opposed the scale of the development due to its impact on the conservation area, but the council approved it with a seven-to-three vote. The buildings earmarked for demolition were deemed no longer functional, and the project aims to preserve tourism while improving living for older people in the town. The applicants, The East Cliff Project LLP, will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The council received support from 246 letters, while 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society wrote to object to the demolition. English Heritage stated that the scale of the development would cause severe harm to the conservation area.

The passage describes the murder of Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, by Jake Vallely, 24, outside a bar in Brecon. Vallely was sentenced to 15 years in prison for murder. His friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of any involvement in the attack. The trial was told that Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and in the hour before the attack was boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon". The passage also includes a family tribute to Pte Boyd, who was described as an "all-rounder" with a promising career ahead of him.

The passage describes an incident where Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left the authority by mutual agreement after an error occurred on election day. The error caused voters to be turned away from all polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council apologized for the problems. The results of the investigation will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

The passage describes a football match between Gateshead and Wrexham, where Gateshead won 2-1. Josh Gillies scored for Gateshead with a free-kick, while Sean Newton scored for Wrexham with a free-kick. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead. The manager of Gateshead, Malcolm Crosby, praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's performance in the second half.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries. Norway comes on top and the worst country is Afghanistan, followed by Mozambique.

The passage describes the OneWeb project, which aims to create a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft to provide broadband internet access to every corner of the globe. The project requires a step-change in satellite manufacturing, with a focus on high volume and low cost production methods similar to those used in car and plane factories. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2019, with a goal of having over 800 spacecraft in orbit by the middle of the decade. The project faces competition from other companies planning similar constellations, but Airbus believes OneWeb has a first-mover advantage. The UK Space Agency is expected to play a key role in regulating the project, particularly in relation to debris mitigation.

The UK government's recent spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. Scottish ministers will have £390m more in spending available to them next year. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. The Scottish government is determined to defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service.

The passage discusses the lack of accessible toilet facilities in town centers and the stress it causes for families with children who need assistance to change. The Changing Places toilets, which have extra features and more space, are recommended for people who need two carers or a hoist to help them transfer onto a bench to change rather than a toilet. However, they are not yet compulsory in larger buildings such as shopping centers, cinemas, and leisure facilities. Campaigners are calling for these to be made compulsory.

The passage describes a formal complaint made by Italian consumers' organisations against McDonald's for allegedly forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. McDonald's denies these claims and says it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees. The European Commission will investigate the complaint.

The passage describes a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, and has since gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a billboard in Holywood playing fields, which has led to a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for the Bangor Grammar pupil.

The UK military is undergoing a shake-up that includes the closure of several barracks and the resettlement of regiments. The closure of Brecon Barracks has been condemned by local MP Chris Davies, who launched a petition against the decision. The closure is part of a larger reorganization that includes the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and the closure of other bases in Wales. The move is expected to affect the livelihoods of many people in the affected areas.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It notes that fishing regions around the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU during the referendum campaign, and that the industry has long disliked the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The Lords review warns that these communities are at risk of being marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice.

The passage describes the leak of classified information by Edward Snowden, a former CIA employee, and the subsequent revelations about the US National Security Agency's (NSA) mass surveillance programs. The NSA has access to a vast amount of personal data, including phone records, chat logs, stored data, and social networking data. The US government confirmed that it requested millions of phone records from US company Verizon, which included call duration, location, and the phone numbers of both parties on individual calls. The NSA also has "backdoor" access to the servers of major technology companies, including Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube, and Apple. The US government argues that the surveillance is necessary for national security, while some experts question its true powers and the extent of its access to personal data.

The passage describes the creation of Open AI, a venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, with the goal of advancing digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity. The organization aims to conduct research without financial obligations, focusing on positive human impact. While some experts warn of potential threats posed by AI, others argue that the risk of harm remains low. Open AI's statement emphasizes the importance of distributing AI technology equitably and ensuring its use aligns with human values.

The passage describes L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite his injuries, he has been nominated to carry the Olympic torch and has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook. However, due to the site's limit of 5,000 friends per personal page, he cannot accept all the requests. The passage also mentions that Parkinson's nomination states that he has not lost his personality or sense of humor despite his brain injury, and that he is determined to prove everyone wrong. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab and walks with crutches, while also raising money for military charities and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother says that the support and friendship he has received have been phenomenal and that he is bouncing and buoyed up.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living below the poverty line. Real median income for households decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%, marking the first annual rise in the Gini index since 1993. Additionally, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.

The passage describes the signing of Jos Buttler to a new contract with Lancashire County Cricket Club until 2019. Buttler, a short-format specialist, has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. The passage also highlights Buttler's talent, experience, and positive influence on the team both on and off the field.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. The BBC understands no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered an interest are finalising their bids with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, said it was important UK recyclers had the chance to prove themselves in the field but she was also keen to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard. She added: "For anyone that has served on a ship it's your home, you've literally been through the wars with it... and you want them to have a noble second life. "My preference is to go for the reef and diving attraction. "We've got to get best value for the

The passage describes the history of Fiji, focusing on the country's struggles with racial and political tensions since 1987. It mentions the 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians that led to the introduction of a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian political supremacy, and the 2000 coup led by businessman George Speight that saw the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet held hostage. The passage also notes the ongoing tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, the descendents of indentured labourers brought from India, and the country's economic challenges, including persistent trade and budget deficits. Finally, it mentions Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 and its reinstatement as a member in 2012 after agreeing to hold free elections in 2014.

The Deputy Foreign Minister of Syria, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. However, Syria missed the Wednesday deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. The shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia, with the second shipment being intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. The US Secretary of State, John Kerry, recently condemned the government's use of barrel bombs in the city of Aleppo, which has resulted in the deaths of 246 people, including 73 children. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims that the Islamic Front coalition, dominated by the Ahrar al-Sham brigade and the al-Qaeda affiliate al-Nusra Front, has mounted an assault, freeing hundreds of detainees. The OPCW has admitted that the process of destroying the chemical weapons has been slowed down by security concerns.

The passage describes the 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, which includes works by authors from various countries. The favorite to win is Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, followed by Howard Jacobson's J. Other authors on the list include Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night.

The passage describes a legal dispute over a man's right to privacy versus the Sun on Sunday's desire to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities. The man, referred to as PJS, has taken legal action to prevent his identity from being revealed in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal and decide if the interim injunction should be allowed or dismissed. The interim injunction will remain in place until the conclusion of the next hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues he has a right to privacy. The story has already been published in the US, Scotland, and elsewhere where the injunction does not apply. The man's solicitors have been assiduous in monitoring the internet and removing stories in breach of the injunction, but the judges said that it is now a "hopeless task."

The passage describes the purchase of Fosse Park by Crown Estates for £345.5m and plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners have met with the Blaby District Council to address potential planning questions and improve the park's quality.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification" by the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF). However, Disney decided to hold the film for a "review" of its content after it emerged it would feature a "gay moment". The LPF approved the screening with a minor edit concerning the gay moment. The film's director, Bill Condon, spoke about the "exclusively gay moment" involving LeFou, the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston. The decision to review the Disney classic in Malaysia courted criticism from netizens.

The passage describes the requirement for landlords to obtain a license for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) if they let properties to more than three unrelated people. Many landlords are deterred from obtaining the license due to its cost, despite facing a fine of up to £20,000. The Southampton City Council estimates that there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. The Shelter helpline advises that tenants often face concerns such as eviction and living in poorly maintained properties due to the shortage of affordable homes. The mandatory licensing for HMOs applies to houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. The licenses affect properties in specific areas of Southampton, and the council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The passage discusses the political situation in Ireland following the general election, where no party was able to form a majority government. The main sticking point is the issue of water charges, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. The acting Taoiseach, Enda Kenny of Fine Gael, and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil hope to avoid a second election and reach an agreement on forming a minority government. However, Fianna Fáil's refusal to support a programme for government poses a challenge.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry, caught fire while traveling to Valencia, Spain. Passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats and rescued by another ship. Three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter. The fire occurred on one of the car decks about 27km from Mallorca. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to assist. The passengers and crew eventually boarded the Puglia ferry. Spanish officials said the rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive at the port in a few hours. Psychologists were being asked to go to the port to provide counseling. The ferry may sink due to the fire.

The passage discusses the issue of duplicate voting applications and the need for better integration between individual electoral registers and the online registration service. It notes that a record number of people registered to vote in the recent election, but concerns remain about the number of duplicate applications. The Electoral Commission recommends clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. The passage also mentions the potential for people to be registered in multiple constituencies and casts more than one vote in local elections, but voting twice in a general election is a criminal offense.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, died by suicide in prison. He was a star player at the University of Nebraska and had a successful NFL career with the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers. However, he faced legal troubles both on and off the field. He was convicted of assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and of assaulting a former girlfriend. Phillips was serving a term of more than 30 years when he was accused of killing his former cellmate. A judge found enough evidence to try him in the death of Damion Soward, 37. Phillips' coach at Nebraska, Tom Osborne, said he was an intelligent person with some good qualities but struggled with anger issues and could not overcome the demons in his life.

The passage describes the promotion of Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, to the rank of lance corporal by the colonel of the Mercian Regiment. The ram was awarded the promotion for "good behaviour" and is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment when it formed in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014 and has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations, and takes his holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. During his career, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

The passage describes a football match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund, where Liverpool won 4-3. The match was played in front of a passionate crowd, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp and Borussia Dortmund's Thomas Tuchel on the touchline. Liverpool needed three goals to win, and Klopp invoked the spirit of Istanbul and the Champions League Final won from 3-0 down at half-time against AC Milan in 2005. Liverpool completed a turnaround with goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and the late drama from Lovren. The match was a testament to Klopp's ability to inspire his players and turn doubters into believers.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, with Mr. Davis stating that the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about negotiations. Mr. Russell called for greater transparency from the UK government regarding its plans. Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. Mr. Russell emphasized the importance of EU market access for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes to overturn the High Court judgment on Article 50, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this in the Supreme Court.

The passage describes a physical examination of a clone sheep named Daisy, who is one of four cloned sheep from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep. The examination includes checking for signs of crepitus or lameness, as well as regular joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans. The goal of the examination is to determine if the cloning process affects the health of the cloned animals, particularly with regards to aging-related diseases such as osteoarthritis. The results of the study will be published next week.

The passage describes a horse race where the unbeaten 4-7 favorite won by a length and three-quarters. The winner will go to Chantilly next rather than the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Shutter Speed, who won the Musidora Stakes, will be prepared for the Oaks at Chantilly. The trainer is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes, but will decide whether to run him in the Derby trial after walking the course.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro, but started recovering in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The "volatility index" has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Against the euro, sterling was down 0.6% at â‚¬1.2605 and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen, although markets have also been rattled by global economic worries. With 10 days to go before the referendum vote, two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They played against a very good Barrow team and conceded a goal after five minutes, which made it tough for them. Despite the loss, Cowley remained positive and said that what they have done so far has been remarkable. He also mentioned that they are a part-time team and this is their toughest challenge to date, but they will embrace it and enjoy it.

The passage discusses the potential shift in planning responsibilities from the Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland. This move aims to democratize the planning system, giving elected politicians more control over planning decisions. However, there are concerns about whether politicians have the necessary skills and knowledge to make informed decisions, as well as potential conflicts of interest and the influence of developers and political parties. The environmental group Friends of the Earth warns that a strict code of conduct will be needed to ensure fairness and transparency in the new planning system.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, causing serious injuries. The cat survived but had to undergo surgery to remove its left back leg. The Scottish government had previously consulted on licensing air weapons, but most responders opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA is calling for the implementation of airgun licensing to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.

The passage describes Liverpool's signing of Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a reported fee of £32m, making him the club's second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012, has signed a long-term contract with Liverpool. The club has struggled for goals in recent seasons, with the departure of Luis Suarez and prolonged injury absences for Daniel Sturridge. Benteke's addition to the squad is seen as a boost to the team's attacking capabilities, with former Villa manager Paul Lambert predicting success for the Belgian international. Former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is also optimistic about Benteke's potential to lead the team's forward line.

The study by education technology charity Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are widely used in schools, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using them. The study, which looked at a representative sample of 671 state and independent schools, found that many pupils reported taking internet-connected devices to bed to continue social media conversations. The study also found that tablets are now being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with academy schools showing the highest use of tablet computers. However, researchers found examples of much more intensive use, with 9% of schools having an individual tablet device for every pupil. The underlying trend is for an increasing number of tablet computers in schools, with the number expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. However, Dr Barbie Clarke, formerly of the University of Cambridge's education department, says it is not possible to make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results. Researchers cannot isolate the impact of technology as the specific cause of a rise in attainment.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the lives of children over 100 years. The photos provide a glimpse into childhood and social history in Liverpool, spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s. The exhibition showcases how much life for children has changed and how special occasions were celebrated on the city's streets. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and depicts the Rollo family, who lived in a large home with four servants. The exhibition has been curated by Kay Jones, who selected the final 25 images from hundreds of photographs in the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

The passage describes two football players, Anderson and Keating, who have signed for Exmouth Town. Anderson, a centre-back, has cancelled his contract at Barrow to join their National League rivals, while Keating, a striker, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The passage describes a new law in Bolivia that permits 12-year-olds to work, but only with parental authorization. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. The law was approved by Congress and signed into law by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, with President Evo Morales traveling to Brazil at the time. The law aims to help eradicate extreme poverty in Bolivia, but the International Labour Organization is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

The passage describes how a 50-year-old woman recognized the symptoms of a heart attack after searching for women's heart attack symptoms online. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked. The woman had a "widow maker" heart attack after helping a woman who was struggling to get out of her car. She did not call emergency services but issued a warning to others to know the symptoms and call 911 if necessary.

A 16-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed to death during a fight at a party in Kenton, London. He was invited to the party, which appeared to be well-run with appropriate adults in attendance. He was not involved in an altercation with a group of youths denied entry to the party, but he was targeted later. A man aged 21 has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A third person, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes how Denmark reorganized its healthcare system to improve cancer diagnosis and treatment. The changes included introducing fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, setting up diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and creating "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The result has been better survival rates and improved organization of healthcare resources.

The passage describes the UK government's decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) and transfer its responsibilities to Powys, which will now issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents. People will still contact their local authority trading standards department for complaints, but Powys will handle cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act. The move is seen as an opportunity for Powys to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The passage discusses a plan proposed by the Nuffield Trust to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to help cover for doctor shortages and improve patient care. The plan involves giving nurses and pharmacists more training to perform tasks currently done by doctors and GPs. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix for problems in the NHS, and there are concerns about the lack of funding for training courses. The British Medical Association and Unison have also expressed concerns about the plan, with the former arguing that it should not come at the expense of good quality training for doctors, and the latter warning that developing the NHS support workforce must not be seen as a quick and cheap fix for chronic shortages of nurses and other health workers.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

The National Rivers Authority (NRW) has estimated that the Swansea tidal lagoon project will result in the death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout each year. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming that they lack a clear scientific basis. NRW argues that its figures are based on the best available evidence. TLP has also claimed that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating the figures. TLP's computer modeling estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% of all species of fish being killed. The UK government is considering the viability of the scheme, which is yet to be published. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths said the Welsh Government is supportive of the scheme but needs clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and believes its figures are the best available evidence.

The passage discusses the announcement of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, which will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The move is aimed at providing strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations in the agri-food industry. The establishment of this body is seen as an opportunity for the Northern Ireland agri-food industry to work together for the benefit of the entire sector. The Agriculture Minister, Michelle O'Neill, welcomes the announcement but notes that the plans could have implications for the work of other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust has organized a project to plant thousands of new trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The project aims to plant "millions" of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. The four-year project is one of the trust's most ambitious planting programmes and uses the pledge: "We will stand for those who fell." The conservation charity plans to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The charity is providing the saplings for members of the public to plant, and has advised volunteers to wear welly boots or "stout footwear".

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday. The book is a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honor crime. The other books on the shortlist were: Sara Paretsky was chosen for the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award after her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago.

The passage describes how Santner broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, which was a blow to their hopes of qualifying. He will rejoin the team following the ICC Trophy in England.

The passage describes the death of Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man who was killed by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. The case demonstrated the difficulty in investigating a case of a death abroad, and the family of Barry Pring believes he was killed in a staged hit and run accident. The inquest heard that Barry's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove and tried to claim his assets within days of his death. The couple met online in 2006 and were married in 2007 following a four-day engagement. The inquest also heard that Ms Ziuzina sold Mr Pring's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death, but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

The passage describes how a boy named Charlie, who has been ill since the age of three, needs to fly to Seattle for experimental treatment that is not available in the UK. The treatment involves T-Cell Therapy, which failed in his last transplant. A donor has paid for the treatment, and the family is grateful for the anonymous donation. The treatment will start as soon as possible once Charlie has financial clearance from the hospital.

Apple has introduced a new security feature called two-factor authentication (2FA) to protect users' accounts from unauthorized access. This feature requires users to enter a four-digit code in addition to their username and password when accessing their iCloud account from a device they have not used before. The code is either sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the user does not enter the code, they are refused access to iCloud and are blocked from making purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. Users can also use a 14-character recovery key to regain access to their account in case their trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple had previously offered the two-step verification system, but it had not been activated when device owners used the firm's backup service. This means that even if people had switched on the two-step feature to prevent cyber-thieves logging into their accounts with a stolen or guessed password, the attackers could still download a complete backup of their data by using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Several hackers' forums contain discussions about using pirated copies of Elcomsoft's "forensic" software, which is marketed as a tool for law enforcement agencies to access iCloud content without needing to

The passage describes a potential deal where Dan Groves, a 30-year-old, may buy 20% of Billericay FC and become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points behind a play-off place. Wright has previously played non-league football for clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who invested £10,000 a week in the club. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley was asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers due to a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright. The BIS select committee, which Mr Wright chairs, has invited Mr Ashley to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. Mr Ashley has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered by the committee and has not agreed in principle to attend. If he fails to respond, the committee reserves the right to take the matter further, including seeking the support of the House of Commons in respect of any complaint of contempt.

The passage describes a report on the conflict in eastern Ukraine, which was never written but has been compiled by the murdered opposition politician's colleagues. The report, titled Putin. War, is based on facts that have appeared in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in 2014. The authors argue that the conflict is a war for President Vladimir Putin's own ends, and that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive to securing all major victories claimed by the pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk.
