The report presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit that it was Russian generals, not separatists, who directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report also documents evidence of Russian spending on the conflict and the salaries of volunteer soldiers. The opposition plans to seek donations to extend the initial print run of only 2,000 copies. However, publishing and distributing this kind of dossier is hard work, and many publishers were afraid to work with this material. The question remains how many people are keen to learn the facts which for months have been available on the internet and the few liberal media that remain in Russia.

Craig Nelson, 34, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire with head injuries. A post-mortem confirmed his death. A man, 41, and a woman, 23, were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

The passage discusses the disagreement between the Welsh government and the UK government over the Article 50 letter, which outlines the UK's plans for Brexit negotiations. The Welsh government, led by Carwyn Jones, complained that they were not consulted on the letter and felt that their devolved powers would be diminished as a result of Brexit. The UK government, led by Theresa May, stated that they would consult with the devolved administrations on the return of powers to the UK, but did not specify which powers would be devolved. The passage also raises questions about whether the devolved administrations will receive funding to support the new powers they are granted.

The passage describes an incident in which two cars were damaged in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his appall at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

The passage describes the ousting of American Apparel founder Dov Charney due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board stated they did not expect Charney to return to the firm. Charney's lawyer denied the allegations and accused the company of invading his privacy. The court filing includes evidence of inappropriate emails and racial slurs directed at female employees by Charney. The company's papers claim Charney repeatedly violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board stated it would be difficult for any company to hire Charney as CEO, executive, or employee due to the risks to the company and shareholders. The company was granted a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage describes a basketball game between Greece and Great Britain that will be played at the Copper Box in London. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Three members of the Greek team will be missing, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game is GB's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts in September. After playing Greece, GB will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as part of their warm-up games before EuroBasket.

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone and its impact on the technology industry. The author reflects on the initial reaction to the iPhone, which was met with skepticism and criticism. However, the author notes that the iPhone has become a transformative technology, changing the way people think about photography and other activities. The author also notes that other companies, such as Amazon and Google, are now following in the footsteps of Apple with innovative products.

The passage describes a series of cat deaths in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, due to antifreeze poisoning. The RSPCA has confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue have ingested the toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen being the latest victim. The cause of death is unclear, but the RSPCA is appealing for people in the area to store pesticides and chemicals safely to prevent further incidents.

The passage describes the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is poised to agree to more austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors. Despite this, Greece's resorts are teeming with tourists, and there are no demonstrations on the streets. The author suggests that this may be because the Greek citizens are curious about why their government is agreeing to such measures, and they may be waiting to see what concessions the government has made to obtain new credit. The author also notes that Greece is suffering from a vicious economic squeeze, which will undoubtedly further impoverish its people. The author calls for creditors to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainably large debts by between a third and a half, and suggests that this new bailout deal could be a path to genuine recovery if Brussels and Berlin avoid triumphalism and manifest debt forgiveness in the face of Athens' capitulation.

The passage describes the return of Ross Kemp as Grant Mitchell to EastEnders for the final episodes of his character's story. His character, Peggy Mitchell, returns to Albert Square after leaving in 2010 to tell her eldest son Phil that her cancer has returned. The episode ends with the announcement that Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes to be screened in the spring. Kemp will return to bring the Mitchell family back together.

The passage describes the tragic story of Alice Ruggles, who was stalked and killed by her ex-boyfriend Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon. The passage also highlights the guilt and regret experienced by Ruggles' parents, who had tried to reassure their daughter about the situation. Despite the signs of danger, none of them realized the seriousness of the situation until it was too late. The passage concludes with the establishment of the Alice Ruggles Trust, which aims to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking and honor Ruggles' memory.

The French firm EDF has approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, but the UK government will consider its backing carefully. Critics warn of environmental damage and potential escalating costs, and the project is being built by foreign governments. One third of the cost is being provided by Chinese investors. The government launched a further review of the project hours after EDF's board voted to approve it.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the applicant's spouse has committed adultery with. However, there is no obligation to provide this information. Naming a third party can add conflict and complexity to the divorce process, according to family lawyers. The online form has been updated to make the legal process more user-friendly, but some people may still choose to name the third party despite the guidance on the form. If the third party is named, they become part of the court case and may incur additional costs if they do not respond.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental policy and commercial forestry in Wales. While successive ministers have encouraged the planting of native, broadleaf trees and better access for walkers and bike riders, conservationists argue that commercial forests are bad for wildlife. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects of forestry development. The Glastir scheme encourages farmers and landowners to plant woodland, and the Woodlands for Wales forestry strategy outlines the government's goals for high-quality woodlands. However, the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as "sexier" than commercial forestry, and the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas. The timber industry is estimated to be worth over £450 million a year to the Welsh economy, but there is a need for more timber to meet long-term targets set by ministers.

The passage describes an incident in which a boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, Scotland. Emergency crews were called to the scene on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The passage describes how the Russian embassy presented medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys, who transported supplies to the Soviet Union during World War II. The Foreign Office initially blocked the medals due to rules against foreign medals, but an exception was made last year and President Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and too many were let off if they did not attend. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. Some of the problems identified were that getting people who lead chaotic lives to work on time is a task in itself. The difficulty has always been organization. Getting people who lead chaotic lives - many of them with drink or drug problems - to work on time is a task in itself. If sanctions are applied, they will end up in prison; if not, the sentence cannot be enforced.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding a comedian who campaigns for economic and political revolution to help poorer people but lives in a luxury home. The article mentions the comedian's response to a TV reporter's question about his accommodation and his tweets about the controversy. The passage also includes the comedian's previous explanations for his actions and his views on inequality and capitalism.

The passage describes the life and work of Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who has made significant contributions to the field of human genomics. He is known for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome, which led to criticism from the scientific community. However, his efforts have helped speed up the process of decoding genes. Venter also founded the J. Craig Venter Institute, where he has worked on creating a synthetic life form called Synthia. He has also conducted a genetic treasure hunt to collect life forms from the ocean.

The passage describes a survey of parents in England who were asked about their children's school lunch habits. The survey found that four out of five children had tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home, and half of the parents said their children had asked for these foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The survey was conducted by the England's School Food Trust and found that about four in ten primary school children in England now eat school lunches, compared to about 46% in Scotland.

The passage describes Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old footballer who is currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. The terms of his move to Italy included an option for Real to buy him back, with the fee reported to be up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three times for Spain in France and has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals, having appeared as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. The passage also mentions that Morata came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, but has been without a team since being released in May. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to a private equity firm. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Fresh & Easy has lost money since opening in 2007 and will close its remaining 50 stores. Tesco will dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand for £150m, but part of that is a loan which may be paid back. If Yucaipa, the private equity firm, is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.

The passage discusses a person who initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and is now focused on winning a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a special guide for getting into martial arts.

The passage describes the retreat of ice fields in the European Alps, particularly in the Mont Blanc Massif. The area covered by ice fields has decreased from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting and mirrors findings of retreat occurring in other sectors of the Alps. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues, who assessed the roughly 600 glaciers in broad areas incorporating various massifs. The team used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, and manual inspection to verify the satellite data. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier of all - La Mer de Glace, which falls over a 1,000m in altitude down Mont Blanc itself.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday knowing victory would all but secure their place. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins from four, with the outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group.

A woman in south London has complained about harassment from Stuart Campbell, a blogger who campaigns for Scottish independence. Campbell has been arrested and released on bail, and the police are investigating the allegations. Campbell denies that the tweets he posted were threatening and accuses the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation.

The People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) wants to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal-friendly version, such as a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned by the Great Northern Railway to encourage visitors to take the train on their seaside breaks to Skegness. However, PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman evokes images of cruelty to animals and suggests that the resort should rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, believes that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by both adults and children and does not want to portray animal cruelty.

The passage describes a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia. Scotland scored several tries, including a penalty try, while Georgia scored two tries. Scotland's coach praised his team's performance, particularly the play of Greig Laidlaw. The match was played in cold and wet conditions, which affected the quality of play.

The passage describes a rugby league match between Widnes and Castleford. Widnes won the match 38-12, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Despite three tries from Castleford's Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Paddy Flynn, Widnes held on to win. The Vikings' victory was assured when Mellor scored a try after Castleford's indecision on a short kick-off. However, Castleford's defense broke down, allowing Patrick to score a try. The match ended with a nervy finish, but Widnes won 38-12.

The passage describes the release of Fawzi al-Odah from the US facility in Cuba, where he had been detained since 2002. The US review panel concluded that he was not a "continuing significant threat" and recommended his release. However, he will now face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. This is the first inmate to be freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The total number of inmates at the US naval base is now 148. President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut down the facility.

The passage describes the Anzac Day commemoration in London, which includes a service at the Cenotaph, a parade, and a service at Westminster Abbey. The event commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The service at Westminster Abbey included the singing of the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was in 1916, when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey. The service at the Cenotaph featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war and the allied operation was an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

The passage describes the return of a football player named Clarkson to his former team, St Mirren, after a brief absence. He has been playing for the U20s and has been keeping his fitness up. He has played for several clubs in the past and has been capped twice for Scotland. The team is currently eighth in the championship and is looking to improve their position in the league.

The passage describes the sale of a turkey firm to a food tycoon named Ranjit Boparan. There were concerns that the new owners would not honor the existing workers' pension scheme, but the union representative stated that productive talks were held and guarantees were given that all current agreements would be honored. The union also clarified that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004 and that its members currently have an alternative pension scheme that is unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. The union representative met with representatives from Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters and stated that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business by investing more in the business, saving costs, and utilizing the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The council leader announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July to allow feedback on the new vessel. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has faced several issues since its launch, including breakdowns, grounding, and damage to cars. Shopkeepers have expressed concern about the impact on their businesses. Compensation for local businesses is being discussed.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It notes that fishing regions around the UK voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU during the referendum campaign and that the industry is at risk of being marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has often been characterized as a disaster for Britain, and many in the fishing community argue that Brexit now offers the industry the chance to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, like Norway. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that looks at the risks and opportunities for the UK industry. The report notes that the most commercial fish stocks are in waters that are shared between the UK and other EU coastal states, and that the vast majority of UK fish are exported, mainly to the EU while a significant proportion of the fish that British consumers eat is imported, often from EU states. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice.

Timothy Geaney admitted downloading images of young boys in erotic poses without sexual activity between April 2004 and February 2014. He was given a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register earlier this year. He has now been removed from the professional register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. The images were found to be of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses with no sexual activity. Geaney was ordered to take part in a special programme for sex offenders. The panel found that Geaney's conduct was "fundamentally incompatible" with being a registered teacher and that there was a pattern of behavior, as opposed to an isolated incident. The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register.

The fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street caused travel delays and led to the suspension of their waste acceptance by the Environment Agency. The fire service found the firm broadly compliant with fire safety laws, but raised concerns about the potential impact on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, unless an appeal is made. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

The Syrian government is trying to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but has missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. The Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, said that a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. The US has condemned the government's use of barrel bombs in the city of Aleppo, but the Syrian government has denied reports that rebels have seized most of the city's central prison. The OPCW has admitted that the process of destroying the chemical weapons has been slowed down by security concerns.

England won the second Test against Pakistan by setting them a target of 457 runs to win, which they achieved with a day to spare. The hosts made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered the bowlers little assistance. The series is expected to be very tight, with England in a good place and likely to win again.

The passage describes the work of the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, who will gather evidence from pensioners and their families to improve the quality of care in residential care homes. The commissioner will review the quality of life and care of older people in residential care, focusing on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner's team will also speak to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. The commissioner's review and recommendations will ensure that those accountable for and running services understand the day-to-day realities of living in residential care in Wales and the action required to deliver the change needed to ensure that older people living in residential care have the best quality of life.

The passage describes the appointment of Sheerin as the new manager of Aberdeen Football Club, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been the player-manager of Arbroath Football Club since 2010 and led them to their first national trophy in 2011. The passage also mentions that Sheerin played for several Scottish clubs and featured for Östersunds in Sweden before moving into coaching.

Swansea City have sacked manager Bob Bradley and will be led by assistant manager Paul Williams and former player Alan Curtis for their next match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new boss as soon as possible, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Swansea were promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and have struggled to maintain their form since then. The club has lost several key players and has not been the same since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. Curtis believes the current Swansea squad is good enough to stay up, and the club has reminded every new signing of how far they have come.

The passage describes the life and work of Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who has made significant contributions to the field of human genomics. He is known for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome, which led to criticism from the scientific community. However, his efforts have helped speed up the process and have led to the creation of a synthetic life form called Synthia. Dr. Venter has also worked on other projects, including sequencing genomes from marine organisms and creating synthetic life forms. Despite facing criticism and lack of funding, he has been able to pursue his scientific goals through his own means.

The Sutton Trust has warned that many apprenticeships in England are of poor quality and too short, with less than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England every year rated at level three, which is equivalent to A-level. The report suggests that fewer than 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared with over half in Germany, which has one of the best vocational education systems. The report also notes that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, and that the majority of these should be at level three for at least three years, with some four-year courses at level four.

The passage describes the victory of a British cyclist, Storey, in a cycling event in Switzerland. She finished more than two minutes ahead of her Polish opponent, Anna Harkowska. Storey is aiming for further Paralympic success at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. Storey won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. She began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

The passage describes the financial struggles of Hereford United, a Conference Premier club, and their eventual expulsion from the league due to failing to meet their debt obligations. The club's financial problems began when they were relegated from the Football League in 2012, leading to declining gate receipts and mounting debts. Despite fundraising efforts by fans and generous donations from other clubs, the club still owed over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand from HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) by the deadline set by the Conference. The club's financial troubles were exacerbated by falling gate receipts, with the average attendance for the 2013-14 season at Edgar Street being little over half the average gate they attracted in League Two just five years ago. The club's failure to meet their debt obligations led to their expulsion from the Football Conference, and they were replaced by Chester FC, who had also been struggling financially.

The passage describes the career of Jack Milner, a former Manchester City player who has won 61 caps for England and holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player. He scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The passage also mentions that he played just three minutes at Euro 2016.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and exponent of the early-music movement, passed away in Cambridge after a long illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for 30 years, making over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His most famous recording was the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and was a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London. He was the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

The boy from Northern Ireland is unable to attend mainstream school due to his special needs and is waiting for a place at a special school. The family has been told that all special schools in the area are full and no time frame can be given for a place. An extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and the hope is that the boy will be able to start there soon. However, the boy's mother is worried that this situation will happen to other families as the special needs school system is packed to capacity. The Education Authority is currently reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is endeavoring to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside.

The Welsh Rugby Union has made a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons, who play at Rodney Parade. The County Football Club has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and has priority over fixtures. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport RFC, Newport Squash Club, and County are all protected under their current agreements. County is two points clear of the League Two relegation with two games remaining and can clinch survival this weekend if they win and rivals Hartlepool lose.

The passage describes the experiences of a man who was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during the civil war in Sierra Leone, and his subsequent work in the Ebola crisis. He was trained to use a gun and initiated into the group, and was threatened with violence if he tried to escape. He managed to escape and went to the capital, Freetown, but was unable to find his relatives. He was later caught while in jail and met a preacher who encouraged him to continue with his schooling and become a leader in rebuilding the nation. During the Ebola crisis, he developed a clinic to bring in suspected cases and educate people about the disease. The passage also provides statistics on the number of deaths from the virus in various countries.

The passage describes the auctioning of a collection of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs to help pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. The collection was raised through a public fundraising campaign that hit its target in just a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was made possible through the spirit of goodwill and determination shown during the negotiations. The collection is important for Staffordshire and would have been sold and scattered around the globe if the money had not been raised. The sale is seen as fantastic news and is considered to be an important part of Britain's cultural development.

The passage describes a potential deal where Dan Groves, a 30-year-old, may buy 20% of Billericay FC, a club in the Isthmian League Premier Division. If the deal goes through, Groves would become a club director. The club is currently eighth in the league, three points behind a play-off place. Billericay FC was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested £10,000 a week in the club. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The Seasiders scored after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso delivered a pinpoint chip into the area, where Jamille Matt turned the ball home from three yards. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe denied Matthew Briggs with a sensational save to push the ball behind after 17 minutes, but the visitors did equalise from the resulting corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from close range after a goalmouth scramble. Colchester failed to re-take the lead on the stroke of half-time as Slocombe produced a brilliant save from George Elokobi's close-range effort, before Guthrie headed against the bar from two yards. Blackpool should have clinched the win 15 minutes from time, as Tom Aldred was found unmarked from a corner, but he headed wide from eight yards. Colchester finished the game with 10 men, after substitute Sean Murray was shown a straight red for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The passage describes a plan to repurpose the disused Fawley power station chimney into a tall attraction in Hampshire, England. The chimney will be the centerpiece of a "merchant city" development that includes a marina, housing, and restaurants. The development will also feature fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The chimney will be transformed into a petal-shaped glass structure, and the entire project is estimated to cost £1 billion. The development is expected to start in 2018, and the architects' plans show that the chimney will be the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard.

The passage describes the results of the Hong Kong championships in track cycling. The 23-year-old Latham emerged from the pack to take bronze in the men's scratch race, chasing down Adrian Teklinski of Poland and Lucass Liss of Germany. In the men's team pursuit, GB were beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, Joe Truman, was outclassed in his semi-final. In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride.

The passage describes Ross Kemp's return to EastEnders to play Grant Mitchell, who last appeared in 2006. He will return to bring the Mitchell family back together as his character's cancer returns. The episode will feature emotional scenes where Peggy, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, will die from the disease.

The passage describes a soccer match between Tottenham Hotspur and Liverpool, where Sadio Mane scored twice for Liverpool within 138 seconds. The match was disappointing for Tottenham, who have struggled to win away from home since September. The article also discusses Tottenham's poor performance against top-six teams away from home and their lack of desire to fight for the Premier League. The article mentions Chelsea's potential to extend their lead at the top of the league table and former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy's analysis of Tottenham's performance.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the People's Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan in the presidential poll. The PDP lost control of key northern states and three states affected by the militant Islamist group Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP's decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which will be of huge concern to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were marred by violence due to stiff rivalry, and the battle for power and money. Ethnic differences also fueled the conflict in some areas, but overall the elections have been more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes that Nigeria's democracy is maturing.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival will offer visitors an app that triggers online information from signs and posters on the site. Videos and band interviews will be available for viewing on phones and tablets. The festival will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, said that the new augmented reality experience is an extra feature to add to the enjoyment of visiting the festival this year. It will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and capture a flavor of its atmosphere at any time.

The passage describes the termination of funding agreements for several Birmingham academies rated inadequate by Ofsted. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools, and Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools said parents tried to undermine her authority and descended on the school during an Ofsted inspection. The watchdog published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover.

The passage describes the death of Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, who died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose, who failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test, was so far below the expected standard that it was criminal. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into engaging in sexual activity with a man he met through an adult website and filming their encounter. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and sentenced to a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland made 165-5 in Greater Noida, but Afghanistan won with two overs to spare. Ireland lost an early blow when Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. The sides will meet again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona has made a tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential interpretations of the contracts signed in the Neymar transfer. The club denies any tax-related crime and believes the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have been held by Thai police and are alleged to have confessed to the murders. The UK Metropolitan Police officers have completed their review of the investigation and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of Hannah and David. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. Post-mortem examinations found that Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA found on Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday knowing victory would all but secure their place. Iceland, ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world, are also unbeaten after four wins from four, with the outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group.

The passage describes how Apple has introduced a new security feature called two-step verification to protect users' accounts from unauthorized access. This feature requires users to enter a four-digit code after typing their username and password into a device they have not used before. If the code is not entered, the user is refused access to iCloud and is blocked from making purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. The process also involves using a 14-character recovery key to regain access to the account in case the trusted device is lost or stolen. The passage also mentions that Apple had previously offered the two-step verification system, but it had not been activated when device owners used the firm's backup service. The passage concludes by discussing the potential risks associated with lost recovery keys and the need for companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google to implement two-factor authentication as the default security measure.

The UKIP, Conservative, and Liberal Democrat parties spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign. UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815, and the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575. The Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning.
Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join their National League rivals, while Keating, 21, has joined Gulls under the recommendation of Micky Adams.

The passage describes the death of an Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds after winning a race at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is a rare occurrence in horses with no underlying health issues. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death, and the trainer described the horse as the "horse of a lifetime." The passage also mentions that the horse had previously won races and had received treatment for overheating, but there is no link between the two conditions.

The passage describes the final speeches of three Scottish politicians as they prepare to leave the Scottish Parliament. The Presiding Officer, Tricia Marwick, sheds tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and SNP leader Alex Salmond bid farewell to the parliament. McNeil warns that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, while Salmond says Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for governing Scotland.

The passage describes the casting of actors for the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, including Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Josh Gad as Gaston's sidekick LeFou. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and is set to be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its plans at a meeting with Hillsborough victims' relatives. The CPS has received files of evidence from 23 suspects related to the 1989 stadium disaster, including 15 from the Operation Resolve investigation into the causes of the disaster and 8 from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct. The families of the victims have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington to be informed of the decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS. The families are determined to never give up their pursuit of accountability.

The passage describes numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall at Chelmsford Prison, with one former inmate stating that the jail is notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice has acknowledged the problem and stated that staff work extremely hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons, but more needs to be done. A woman living near the prison has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, and the former inmate claims drones are used to fly contraband goods straight up to prison windows. The Ministry of Justice has introduced laws that could result in up to two years in jail for those who smuggle packages over prison walls.

A 72-year-old woman named Sylvia Blackburn suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside a school in Bedfordshire. Wright, who admitted striking Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, said he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a middle-distance runner who will miss the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She plans to focus on completing her degree and potentially competing in the World Indoor Championships in March.

The passage describes the investigation into the disappearance of Trevor Deely, who was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a site in Chapelizod in Dublin started early on Saturday morning, and the search will involve excavations and is expected to take a number of weeks. The search is based on CCTV footage from the night Deely went missing, which shows him talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked. Detectives believe the man seen in the CCTV footage was the same man captured on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road. The man seen in the CCTV has not yet been identified, and detectives are appealing for him to come forward.

The passage describes a tennis match between Del Potro and Wawrinka, where Del Potro won 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. Del Potro is currently ranked 165th in the world due to injury problems, but he is playing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after having three wrist operations. The passage also mentions other matches and players in the same half of the draw as Del Potro, including Andy Murray, Lucas Pouille, Donald Young, Nick Kyrgios, and Feliciano Lopez.

The passage describes the events surrounding Tunisia's and Morocco's participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially facing expulsion from the tournament due to complaints it lodged against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) during the 2017 Nations Cup. However, after a meeting with CAF President Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia was allowed to participate in the tournament. Morocco was also initially banned from participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw due to a ban imposed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) on its participation. However, CAS overturned the ban and reduced the fine imposed on Morocco's Football Association from $1 million to $50,000. The passage also mentions that Equatorial Guinea stepped in to stage the 2015 finals after Morocco refused to host the tournament due to concerns over importing the Ebola virus.

The passage discusses the current struggles of the McLaren Formula 1 team, which has won numerous championships in the past but is currently facing difficulties due to issues with their Honda power unit. The team has two world champions in their lineup, including Fernando Alonso, who is considered one of the best drivers on the grid. The slump started in 2013 when the team lost its way on chassis design, but they seem to have regained their mojo with the car. However, the problems lie with the Honda power unit, which is a far cry from the previous era of one of the most famous partnerships in F1 - it is with Honda that McLaren achieved their greatest successes of an illustrious history. The team's last constructors' title was in the first of those two years of victories with the 'flying Finn'. The team's current predicament is nothing surprising as McLaren's F1 history has been a cycle of triumph and decline.

The passage describes a incident where paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police arrived later and found several people still at the bar. Till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the closure of the bar for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, of Kevin Lynch Park in the town, was charged with two counts of allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. James Thomas, 44, of the same address, faced one count of the same charge. The judge said Ms O'Neill, who is the license holder, had "an appalling record" and expressed concern that he did not have power to impose a custodial sentence. Ms O'Neill was also fined £3,000, while Mr Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA three-point record as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry scored 45 points, including eight three-pointers, to lead the Warriors to a 116-105 victory. Curry's previous record was 272 three-pointers in a single season, which he set two years ago. The Warriors' Klay Thompson also contributed with 26 points. The Trail Blazers' LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, while Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In other games, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds. Derrick Rose scored 12 points for the Bulls, continuing his comeback from injury. The Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

The passage describes how Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when Dutch free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. Van Velzen, who is a YouTube star known for his free-kick skills, had won the opportunity to meet the Anfield stars and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, it became clear to the players that they were not dealing with a regular fan as van Velzen showcased his skills in front of goal. The players were impressed by van Velzen's skills and his ability to make them laugh.

The passage discusses the benefits of removing ovaries for women carrying the BRCA1 gene, which increases their risk of breast and ovarian cancer. A study found that removing ovaries after a breast cancer diagnosis reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by more than 60%. Women with a BRCA1 mutation who had their ovaries removed within two years had a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never underwent the procedure. The study also found that oophorectomy was particularly effective for survival benefit in women with estrogen receptor-negative breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe and Tina Lowe, were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train, the Carolinian, was headed from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay did receive treatment. The train continued on its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. Authorities say the couple may have lived in a homeless camp. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing on its way.

The passage describes Carlos Toro, a former Medellin Cartel member who spent 27 years working as an undercover operative for the DEA in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. However, he is now facing deportation after declining health forced him to retire. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship application, and he fears for his life if returned to Colombia. His work as an informant helped carry out undercover stings around the world, including the prosecution of ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega and cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder.

The US body regulating internet addresses is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for allegedly using the "sucks" domain name to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities and companies seeking to protect their reputations. The company has registered names including YouTube.sucks, Bing.sucks, Visa.sucks, BankofAmerica.sucks, Yahoo.sucks, TelusMobility.sucks, and others. Kevin Spacey is reportedly among those who have paid to have their name removed from one of the "sucks" domains, which opened on March 30. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. ICANN has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the privilege of registering a "sucks" domain, but Vox Populi CEO John Berard claims that most of the names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. The advisory body says that the threat of opening a "sucks" site to the average consumer later is "an essential element of Vox Populi's coercive scheme."

A mother of a baby boy was arrested 27 years after his body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury's bag floating on a village pond. Police exhumed the boy's body from his grave in Norfolk last year after the case came up for periodic review. A DNA sample eventually led them to his mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained how the baby had been stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. She explained how she had placed her dead baby in the pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter on June 5, 1988, just a few days before it was found by teenagers on a Sunday afternoon outing. The boy's body was exhumed by officers as part of a case review, with DNA samples leading police to the boy's mother. He has now been reburied at Weasenham St Peter Church, Norfolk. Police said they have ruled out any foul play and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. The driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed the passenger, Kristopher Hicks, was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. However, when Hicks objected, Young continued driving for almost a mile, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20 mph. Hicks now requires round-the-clock care from his mother and was awarded damages by a judge who ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned him. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided, but is set to be around 50% of what the family had requested and thought to be hundreds of thousands of pounds.

The passage describes several tornadoes that occurred in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. The tornadoes caused damage to buildings and trees, and there were reports of wind damage and flooding in Potosi, Missouri. The National Weather Service predicted more storms in the Midwest and other regions on Thursday.

The passage describes a upcoming fight between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida in New Jersey. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory since losing to Vitor Belfort two years ago and has a title shot in his sights. He believes that he needs to come forward and dominate Machida, who likes to run around and dance, by cutting him off and slowly progressing. Rockhold also mentions that he has seen little things that Machida doesn't like and that he has everything to his game, including taking him down, kicking, and punching. Machida, on the other hand, is confident that he can upset Rockhold and earn himself a title shot.

The passage describes a light general aviation aircraft that touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off back into the air, but the plane's propellers were damaged in the collision with the runway. The pilot managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common causes of a gear-up landing are human error and mechanical fault. The FAA is investigating the incident.

The passage discusses Manchester City's struggles this season, including their poor Premier League defense and the disappointment of manager Manuel Pellegrini in midfielder Yaya Toure's performances. Despite this, Pellegrini has vowed to support Toure until the end of the season. The team is also facing the possibility of selling Toure in the summer due to their desire to overhaul an aging squad. Additionally, the passage mentions the potential transfer of West Ham United's Aaron Cresswell to Manchester City or Chelsea.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the Godfather of Uxbridge, was sentenced to seven years in prison in Italy for being a member of the Cosa Nostra in 1999. However, his sentence expired in October 2014, and his European arrest warrant was to be withdrawn. Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court, according to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).

The passage describes the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of the three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. Mr Mole will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville in place of injured Barry Geraghty. Mr Mole will be AP McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will not be finalised until Friday morning. The other runners in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

The passage describes the murder of Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and her mother, Virginia, was advised against seeing the crime scene photos. However, Virginia eventually decided to see the photos and now regrets not doing so earlier. Jerome Sydney Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. He revealed that his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 was the most important day of his career. McIlroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles after Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. McIlroy has just one top-10 finish to his name in six Masters appearances, finishing joint eighth last year despite the embarrassment of being outscored by his marker in the third round. McIlroy is hoping to complete his Grand Slam of majors with a victory at Augusta later this month.

The passage covers various trending stories, including rainbows appearing in the sky after a rainstorm, exotic dancers being hired at wakes in rural China, RDJ's interview about his private life, lip plumping becoming a trend, a 102-year-old woman going back in time with the help of filmmakers, a school's promposal being accused of racism, Ewan McGregor playing Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast, Johnny Depp's nearly unrecognizable appearance in Black Mass, and a military dad photobombing his son.

The passage describes the alarming number of children born with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) due to maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy. In England, 272 children were hospitalized last year due to FAS, but the actual number affected may be higher. The World Health Organization estimates that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb. The passage also highlights the challenges faced by children with FAS, such as difficulties with dressing, lack of sense of danger, and inability to live independently. The passage concludes with a call for stricter guidelines on alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

The passage describes an attempted robbery at a store in Shildon, County Durham, where the shopkeeper and his wife fought off the attacker using a baseball bat. The attacker, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was previously known as "Boomerang Boy" due to his tendency to return home after committing crimes. He was convicted of attempted robbery and sentenced to six years in jail.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang-raping a young woman at a party in Canada. They have been given bail conditions requiring them to live on a Canadian naval base for several years, surrender their passports, and continue working for the Royal Navy. The alleged assault took place after a hockey game at a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The sailors will appear in court on May 27th.

The passage describes a mother named Valerie Jackson whose four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease. The disease causes RJ's skin to appear red and scaly, and he requires regular treatment with creams to prevent it from drying out. However, a stranger reported Valerie to the police for child abuse, causing her to be surrounded by armed police. The stranger mistook RJ's skin condition for signs of abuse. The passage also highlights the challenges Valerie faces in raising RJ, including cruel taunts from bullies and the difficulty of explaining his condition to others. Despite these challenges, Valerie remains hopeful that RJ's condition will be better known as he grows older.

The passage describes a controversy over an advertisement for protein world, featuring a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield, which has been causing a stir among feminists and body image activists. The advertisement has been defaced by bloggers and has received over 200 complaints from people saying that it promotes an unhealthy body image. Transport for London (TFL) has revealed that the controversial posters around the London Underground, featuring Renee Somerfield, are being removed. The advertising standards authority has also received more than 200 complaints from people saying that the adverts promote an unhealthy body image. The posters are now being removed from the London Underground. The removal of the posters comes as a protest organized against protein world in Hyde Park on May 2 gathers steam. The online fitness store Protein World, who claim that the image is entirely unphotoshopped, have been actively engaging in the furore on social media, strongly defending their campaign with some biting responses to aggrieved tweeters.

The passage describes how rail firms are facing criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from the main party leaders to freeze prices. The Prime Minister has requested First Great Western to review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. The planned changes have angered Mr. Cameron's constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. Train companies have three windows every year in which they can increase "unregulated" fares, which make up around half of their total revenue. The passage also mentions other sharp price hikes being introduced by other rail firms.

A former soldier named John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred when Young went to confront the attackers after they had thrown stones at his property. He suffered an open wound to his forehead and a serious injury to his left eye, which doctors were unable to save. The attack occurred just three weeks after Young and his new wife, Elaine, 54, got married. Police have launched an investigation into the attack but said there appears to be no motive.

Tom Poynton, a wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension after successfully returning from a leg injury sustained in a road accident that killed his father. He missed the entire 2014 campaign due to the injury and underwent an ankle operation before making his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and hard work in preparation for his return, and expressed hope that the new contract would give him confidence to perform well this summer.

The passage describes the story of Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy who was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Despite the severity of his condition, he used a ninja turtle mask to help him feel stronger during radiotherapy treatment. The mask was decorated by hospital staff, and Harley's story gained worldwide attention. After a year of battling the disease, doctors gave Harley and his parents the news that he was cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he remains free of the disease.

The passage discusses Tim Sherwood's advice to Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career instead of his international future. Grealish is currently at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England, and Sherwood wants him to continue forcing his way into the Villa first team. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season, and his dad Kevin believes that he should concentrate on his club football first.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jets, which can vary greatly depending on the location. The fees are highest at airports in Japan, with Haneda Airport being the most expensive at £ 4,559 ($ 6,850) per landing. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Japan, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, and Dublin Airport in Ireland. The passage also notes that owning a private jet is a luxury only affordable to the wealthy, and that the industry is growing with 2.5 million private flights recorded in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe.

The passage describes how Cooper, a Labrador Retriever, enjoys eating ice cream quickly at McDonald's and Starbucks. The owner, Katie Gallegos, runs a dog resort and insists that it's okay for dogs to eat ice cream occasionally. Some viewers have criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she defends her decision, saying that Cooper is healthy and that Daisy, her other dog, only gets a few licks because of her size. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched over seven million times.

Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been given the job permanently after a successful interim period. He signed a three-year deal and has lost just once in seven games since taking over. Locke previously worked as an assistant boss to Allan Johnston at Hearts before taking control of the team when Johnston left. The 41-year-old will speak at a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother is accusing a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son because of essential oils he wears to help combat his illness. The oils, which are manufactured by Doterra, are applied to the child's head and neck and are believed to help him stay calm and focused. However, a teacher's aide complained about the smell of the oils, leading to the threat of suspension. The mother claims that her son has been using the oils all year and that they have a positive impact on him. Despite the threat of punishment, the mother plans to continue fighting the decision. The Lake County School District has stated that it will not suspend the child, citing it as a health issue.

The passage describes a fire that destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, New York. The fire started around 3 PM on Wednesday and spread through 90 condos before collapsing the building. It is not known what caused the fire, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews were deployed to control the flames, but they were unable to enter the summer homes. The fire manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything in the fire. The fire chief said that the wind was offshore, which helped them combat the fire.

The passage describes Queen Elizabeth II's love for horses and her riding habits. She enjoys riding her faithful black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf instead. The passage also mentions her first pony, Peggy, and her love for Fell ponies, which she breeds at Hampton Court. The passage provides information about the history and characteristics of Fell ponies, including their origins and uses throughout history.

A Brisbane neighbor was allegedly killed by a single punch from a 28-year-old man during an argument over noise levels. The deceased was reportedly making loud noises in his yard at 9 pm on Thursday night, while the other neighbor worked a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse. The deceased's defense lawyer stated that the neighbor was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at others. The neighbor confronted the deceased, and the situation escalated, resulting in the punch that killed the deceased. The neighbor was granted conditional bail and ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the local police station twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

The passage describes a case where a jilted music teacher, Yulia Simonova, wanted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova was arrested by police after she handed over some expenses money to an undercover police officer posing as a hitman. She faces 15 years in prison after being charged with attempted murder.

The passage describes Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho's religious beliefs and his efforts to separate his professional and personal lives. He revealed that he talks to God every day, but never about football, and he has been an ambassador against hunger. He also admitted that he has a strong faith in God and tries to support people he doesn't even know. The passage also mentions that Mourinho was fined £25,000 by football authorities for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea after Cesc Fabregas was booked for diving against Southampton.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price Is Right" for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1st. He hosted the first price-guessing game of the show, the classic "lucky seven," before handing over the hosting duties to Drew Carey, who finished up the show. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker didn't seem to miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was posted with the Foreign Missions Branch, which deals with the United States' diplomatic activities. Court records show that Baldwin will be arraigned on Friday.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. He got out of his car and crept up to the lion, armed only with a camera. The lion was treated as prey and attacked Atif, forcing him to retreat quickly. Atif managed to capture a couple of frames before retreating to safety.

The passage describes the discovery of an unidentified woman's body in Brooklyn, New York City, with a distinctive heart tattoo that reads "Monique." The woman was found unconscious on March 22 and pronounced dead that evening. The police are seeking information from anyone who may have knowledge of the woman or her circumstances.

The passage describes how a New Zealand couple built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a flatbed truck after returning from living in the UK. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent a year and a half building the home, which is made of wood and steel. The couple now lives in the home, surrounded by nature, and is nearly self-sufficient, with most of their electricity coming from solar panels.

The passage discusses a study conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University in the US, which found that children who shared iPads in class performed significantly better in early literacy tests compared to those who did not use the devices. The study involved 352 kindergarten students at a midwestern suburban school district and found that shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher in a test than students who used the device on their own and non-iPad users. The researchers suggested that the collaborative learning around the technology made the difference, not just the collaboration in and of itself. The study's findings suggest that schools should reconsider how they use tablets, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

The passage describes a piglet born without hind legs that has learned to walk on its front trotters. The piglet has become an internet sensation after a heartwarming video of it taking unsteady steps and foraging for food went viral. The piglet belongs to a farmer in Sichuan Province, China, and has captured the hearts of many. The piglet's two-legged ability is due to its extraordinary balance, and it is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to win plaudits in China.

A pit crew member named Todd Phillips was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Phillips was hit by Dracone's car on lap 25 while exiting the pit box. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released from the infield care center. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain that fell for hours before the green flag. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd.

The passage describes a horrific incident where a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally attacked and killed his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, after accusing her of being unfaithful. The husband, who is a 32-year-old man, admitted to the murder and stated that he was jealous of other men looking at his wife. The attack was captured on CCTV footage, which showed the husband smacking his wife's head against concrete and shooting her in the face multiple times. The victim belonged to a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas. The husband was arrested after fleeing the scene in a stolen car. He now faces life in jail.

The passage describes Sarah Wilson's personal battle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, which led her to consider suicide. She attributes her struggles to a combination of issues such as stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and isolation. Wilson acknowledges the link between depression and anxiety and believes that society needs to better address these issues. She encourages people to seek help if they or someone they know is struggling with mental health.

The passage describes an Oregon woman named Elena Curtin who was seven months pregnant when she was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. The ex-girlfriend was found shooting heroin in Curtin's bathroom. However, the charges were dropped because Curtin was deemed "completely justified in her outrage." The ex-girlfriend was described as "jealous and bitter" towards Curtin's boyfriend, who had struggled with heroin in the past. The boyfriend and ex-girlfriend have since reconciled and Curtin is now living with her parents. If Curtin had gone to trial and been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

The passage describes Gemma, a pit bull, who is fed treats at home in California. Her owner tries to trick her by adding a broccoli spear to the treats, but Gemma pulls a disgusted expression and spits it out on the floor. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized for directing visitors to a pornographic page through a link on its official website. The link was a result of the Young Entrepreneur Awards being scrapped in 2011, and the organizers allowed its registration on HSBC's website to expire. HSBC has removed the hyperlink from its main website and apologized to the public for any inconvenience caused. The bank insists that its website remains secure and that it is not associated with the external site.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton on Sunday. Marcus, who stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, instructed the dispatcher to rescue his siblings who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. He also soothed his sister after she blurted out, "we're going to die," during the call. Firefighters were able to rescue Marcus and his sister, and the other three family members escaped on their own. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members were taken to MedStar Hospital.

The passage describes the emergence of blue fluorescent algae in Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. The photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow illuminating one of Australia's popular beaches. The algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, is a single-celled phytoplankton that gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism. The algae blooms in the spring and autumn and is caused by natural factors.

The passage describes how new genetic tests can help breast cancer patients avoid chemotherapy by determining the aggressiveness of their tumor. The tests involve sending cancer cells to a lab for screening, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as five percent, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given chemotherapy following removal of the tumor to prevent recurrence, but the side effects can be difficult to live with. The passage also mentions that the newest of the tests, called endopredict, shows a low score for some women, allowing them to opt not to have chemotherapy. The tests are currently available privately and cost about £ 2,500, but breast specialists hope they may soon become available on the NHS.

The passage describes how more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. One ship, HMS Ocean, had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency "medevacs" during the last nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before it was decommissioned last year. The Ministry of Defence confirmed that there was a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea, suggesting that the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave.
