The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims she had a sexual relationship with a member of her crew. The Ministry of Defence would not confirm what these reasons were or what action she would face. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female.

A drone carrying traces of a radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House on Wednesday, raising concerns about the potential for terrorism involving drones. The discovery comes amid a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant in Kagoshima Prefecture, more than four years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many Japanese, who view nuclear energy as too dangerous. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of a radioactive material believed to be cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The government will do all it can to prevent terrorism.

The passage describes a security guard named Lu Xincai from Zhejiang Province in China who takes his 84-year-old mother with him to work every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he is scared she will get lost if he leaves her at home alone due to her Alzheimer's disease. Lu Xincai's father passed away earlier this year, and he decided to take his mother to work because there was no one else who could look after her. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai helps his mother get up at 5 am every morning, puts her on the back seat of his motorbike, and ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure that she does not fall off. The journey takes an hour, and even when at work, he checks up on his mother, who has been given her own room by his employers, a bank. Lu Xincai feels like he has a duty to care for his mother in return for all the care she gave him when he was young.

The passage describes a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington that found a rise in heavy drinking among Americans, particularly among women. The study also found that binge drinking rates have increased significantly among women, with a rate increase of more than seven times the rate among men. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. The increase in binge drinking is attributed to changing social norms, particularly among women, and the availability of cheaper alcohol. Public health experts offer various cultural and economic explanations for the increase in excessive drinking.

The passage discusses the risks associated with performing cesarean sections too frequently, particularly in England where the rate has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that cesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to infections and even death. The WHO recommends that the rate of cesarean sections should ideally be between 10-15%, while the current rate in England is over 25%. The passage also notes that planned cesarean sections cost more than natural births and that the procedure can lead to significant complications, disability, or death. The passage contrasts the WHO's recommendations with current NHS guidelines, which allow for planned cesarean sections even when there is no medical justification.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, has been arrested for breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived inside for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. The owner of the property, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins sitting in his living room and called the police. Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when Conklin called the police. Filkins was arrested several hours later after attempting to get back into the home. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

The passage describes how a lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke was reunited with her after police posted photos of the phone on her Facebook page. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning, and officers used it to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the police station on Bella's Facebook page. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before and realized she had lost it when she tried to call her number. By the time Bella made it to the police station, the original post had already garnered a humorous response from her friends and officers. The phone was eventually claimed by Bella, who put a password on her phone.

The passage describes a tragic incident where a five-day-old baby hippo was killed during a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as the baby was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface. The two adult hippos had been fighting for some time, and the mother of the calf stayed with her herd, believing it was safer to stay out of harm's way. However, one of the brawling adults grabbed the calf between its jaws, and the baby died of its injuries hours later.

The passage describes a three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, which is being sold for £575,000. The property has just three years left on the lease, which would cost £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month. However, if the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The apartment is described as "bright and well proportioned" and has 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a communal garden. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson for the same price as a three-bedroom house in Stanmore, Middlesex. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and any buyer would have to negotiate a lease extension with them.

The passage describes a computer outage at Starbucks that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The outage was resolved on Saturday, and stores were expected to operate as usual. The cause of the outage was not explained. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Twitter users shared photos of their free drinks, and some stores closed early. The outage came one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings.

The passage describes how terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. The training is being conducted by the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, and the individuals involved are described as taking part in seemingly ordinary activities while having an ulterior motive. The rugged terrain of the area is being used to prepare soldiers for warfare, and incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998. The passage also mentions the involvement of individuals who studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanbydder, and who were later involved in terrorist plots.

The passage describes the discovery of an Omura's whale on a remote beach in Western Australia, which is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The whale was identified using DNA profiling, and its carcass has been buried while its skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possible public display. The Omura's whale is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan and has a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin.

The passage discusses the impact of hormones on decision-making and leadership, particularly in relation to presidential candidates. It highlights concerns about female candidates, such as Hillary Clinton, and the belief that their hormones may make them irrational and prone to starting unnecessary wars. The passage also mentions studies showing that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts and argues that discussions about a candidate's hormones are a sign of the state of presidential politics being depressing. The passage concludes by discussing the bias against women in the workplace and the benefits of eradicating gender stereotypes.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and "Harry Potter," is selling his extensive collection of antiques in a £100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The auction includes over 200 items collected over his career, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, cabinets made by Gillows of Lancaster, and a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow. The auction will be held at Dominic Winter Auctioneers' saleroom in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, on Saturday.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is wanted by authorities as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. An initial investigation determined there was foul play. Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His estranged wife filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago. Neighbors believe divorce proceedings may have pushed Shemansky over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon, but it is still not publicly identified. Anyone with information about Shemansky's whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations Council, who saw it as a unique strategic opportunity to host the championships for the first time in the USA. Eugene failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. Eugene's recent presentation to the IAAF convinced the governing body that the city has what it takes to stage a world championships. The IAAF President, Lamine Diack, stated that the council made a strategic decision to take advantage of a unique opportunity that may never arise again, where public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic Committee, NBC, and a particularly enthusiastic public are joining forces. The 2007 World Championships held in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10000 metres during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

An aspiring model named Leonie Granger, 25, lured a professional gambler named Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in a bid to steal his winnings. Granger used her good looks to befriend Hassan, who showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. Granger took advantage of Hassan being a "soft target" and, after going back to his flat with him one night, made her excuses and left the door unlocked so her boyfriend and an accomplice could get inside. They tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home to find his hidden winnings. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years in prison. Her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years.

The passage describes Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas' struggles during the second half of the season, including his poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite his success earlier in the season, his form has significantly dipped, and questions remain about his durability. The passage also mentions his struggles in midfield, his role as a key man in the Blues' title charge, and his potential to break Thierry Henry's record for assists in a Premier League season.

West Ham are discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford after he impressed on trial. Beckford, a skilled 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, has been invited to train with West Ham's academy and has impressed coaches after spending two weeks with the club. Beckford also has offers from clubs in Belgium and is said to be one of the hottest prospects to emerge from the Caribbean. Premier League outfit West Ham are closing in on the signature of Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford. Meanwhile, West Ham have revealed season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289. The Hammers will have the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League in a bid to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium when they make the switch for the 2016-17 season.

The passage describes a vicious assault on a huntsman named Mike Lane by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of the suspected attacker, the police have dropped the investigation. The victim, who was beaten and kicked in the head, has suffered memory loss and has been told by police that further evidence is needed to identify the attackers. The police have stated that they are shelving their inquiries due to insufficient evidence. The passage also mentions that the police have issued the suspect's photograph, but he has not been identified. The countryside alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing a face covering so criminals can be brought to justice.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and Al Qaeda operative, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. He was not specifically targeted, but his death was linked to the death of another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, who was also an Al Qaeda operative. Gadahn was known as the American mouthpiece of Al Qaeda, speaking against his native country on behalf of the terrorist organization. He was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995. He grew up on a farm in rural California and moved in with his paternal grandparents, who were Jewish. He was known as Abu Suheyb after joining Al Qaeda and became its chief official English-language propagandist. He was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" and was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al Qaeda.

The passage describes a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old and has displayed impressive skills in a viral video. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at the same time. His skills have won him many fans in China, and he is being compared to Yao Ming, China's biggest basketball star.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which advocated for child sex legalization in the 1970s and 1980s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25th to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation, which it believes is biased and unfair. The group wants MPs to establish a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off has been an embarrassment to the group.

The passage describes how the iconic Icebergs Club pool in Bondi was drained to serve as a unique catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show featured a collection of ten unisex pieces that could be worn in 20 different ways, and was attended by a crowd of spectators who enjoyed the minimalist, androgynous designs and the beautiful ocean backdrop.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. He posed with a rare white tiger, fed it, and also took pictures with giraffes and sea lions. Khan announced that his next fight will be against Chris Algieri at the welterweight on May 30.

A Palestinian teenager's name was removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and others complained. The teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His father refused to allow his son's name to be included on the memorial wall, and the organization representing victims of terror in Israel also opposed his inclusion. The national insurance institute of Israel agreed to remove Abu Khdeir's name following his father's complaint.

The passage describes a young boy who uses his cat's belly as a pillow instead of a feather down pillow. The boy chases the cat around the garden to get it to lie down for him to rest on. The cat initially sits and licks its fur before the boy sits on top of it. After a brief moment of stillness, the cat gets up and moves to another spot. The boy follows the cat to its new location and rolls to the ground to rest. The cat eventually decides it's had enough and wanders off indoors. Later, the boy and cat make up and the boy gently feeds the cat treats.

The passage describes a police corruption trial in Philadelphia where a witness named Robert Kushner lost his varsity coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his years selling marijuana. The trial involves allegations of police wrongdoing and includes testimony from more than a dozen former drug dealers. One of the witnesses, Kushner, admitted to being arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, as well as pleading guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, and the government's case is based on 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

The passage describes an explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province that resulted in a fire and injuries to six people. The plant produces paraxylene, a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in the production of polyester. The explosion occurred after an oil leak and was contained by over 600 firefighters. The plant has faced protests in the past due to pollution concerns and was relocated to its current location in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to superstition. He plans to continue this practice after making his first Premier League start on Tuesday night. Despite some referees' attempts to persuade him otherwise, Grealish intends to keep his socks low and shinpads small. He was pleased with his first Premier League start against QPR, despite the game ending in a 3-3 draw.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother. She remains unresponsive and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat. Her father, Bobby Brown, stated that her condition had improved and that she was awake. However, doctors have indicated that she will have a long life and that the quality of her life will not be known for years to come.

Russia is on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki on Saturday. Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets in the opening rubber. Pavlyuchenkova said Lisicki's power caused her problems. The result left Russia needing one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and bag a first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage due to another storm predicted to hit the region later this week. The state emergency service has received over 4,000 job requests for clean-up efforts after last week's storm, with 4,409 still needing to be completed. The Hunter region, which suffered from flooding and high winds in the last storm, is particularly at risk. The Bureau of Meteorology has warned of heavy rain and strong winds in the state's northeast, with peak rainfall expected between Thursday and Saturday. The state emergency service is urging residents to prepare their homes and families for further loss and devastation.

The passage describes a model named Nina Moric who was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media reported that she tried to take her own life, but she denied this claim and stated that she was recovering at home. The model's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she had tried to commit suicide. However, the model's Instagram posts showed bruises on her arms, and she explained that she fell and hurt herself due to low blood pressure. The model was previously married to a famous paparazzi snapper named Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

The British public is eagerly anticipating the arrival of the second child of Kate and William, with many hoping for a baby girl. A new poll reveals that Diana is the favorite name for a girl, followed by Alice and Charlotte. For a boy, James and Alexander are the top choices. Many people hope for a girl, and if one is born, they would like to see the baby named after Diana. The poll also shows that the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded dozens in eastern Afghanistan during a protest against the provincial governor. An Afghan lawmaker was among the wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed it yet. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

The passage describes Dani Alves' decision to leave Barcelona after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has enjoyed a successful seven-year tenure at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he has been unable to agree a new deal with the club and will leave the Nou Camp this summer. Alves' agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that Alves had rejected a three-year contract extension, dependent on playing in 60% of matches for the club.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old soccer player, has suggested that Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti join him at Boca Juniors in Argentina. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for Boca and that the fans would love to see them play on the La Bombonera pitch. Osvaldo has scored three goals in six games since joining Boca on a loan deal from Southampton. Pirlo is considered one of the best midfielders in the world, while Totti is a Roma legend.

The passage describes Lewis Ferguson's fall from his horse during a race at Wincanton. Despite the fall, Ferguson suffered only a minor injury and is determined to continue riding. The fall has become an internet sensation, with millions of people watching the footage online. Ferguson reflects on the experience, stating that he was unable to process what had happened until he saw the replay. He also mentions receiving support from fellow jockeys and some negative comments on social media. Ferguson expresses a desire to pursue a gymnastics career after finishing his racing career.

The passage describes the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie and how James Haskell, a London Wasps captain, dressed up as Iron Man from the movie and posted the photo on his Instagram page. The passage also provides information about Haskell's rugby career, including his time spent playing in France, Japan, and New Zealand.

The wide leg trouser is a trend that is gaining popularity in the fashion industry. It is versatile and can be worn with various types of clothing such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped. The wide leg trouser offers an effortless look and can be a welcome change from the skinny jean. The trend has been around before, particularly in the 1970s, and has made a comeback. However, it can be intimidating for shorter individuals, but the key is to wear high heels and keep the top half simple. Denim is the easiest way to achieve the trend, and it can be found in vintage washes. The wide leg trouser can be paired with a simple knit or shirt to keep the outfit in proportion.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. More than 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie as part of UMIX, a series of social events the university stages for students. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Kyle was fatally shot at a Texas shooting range in 2013. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region. Michigan's Detroit metropolitan area is home to the nation's largest Arab-American population. But there was a backlash to the decision to yank the movie, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. On Wednesday, E. Royster Harper, University of Michigan's vice president for student life, said in a statement that "it was a mistake to cancel the showing of the movie 'American Sniper' on campus as part of a social event for students" and that the show will go on. The announcement drew praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire with an aerosol spray and lighter on Rottnest Island in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The two men, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are small animals found on some small islands off the west Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island near Albany.

The passage describes how 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer in New York nightclubs during the 1930s and 1940s, was able to see herself dancing again after all her photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years. Mark Cantor of Jazz-on-Film.com and some volunteers put together a video of early music videos called "soundies" and showed them to Barker at the nursing home where she lives. Barker was delighted to see herself dancing again.

The passage describes a decline in the practice of washing cars by their owners in Britain. According to a survey by OSV, 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do so regularly. The survey also found that 75% of women never wash their own car, with drivers more likely to take it to a car wash on a local forecourt. The decline in car washing is attributed to various factors, including the rise of hand car washes, the size of modern cars, and the lack of interest among children in earning pocket money by washing cars. The passage also notes that cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, while they are least likely to be washed in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

The passage discusses Steven Gerrard's impact on Liverpool FC and his upcoming departure from the club. Martin Skrtel, a teammate of Gerrard's, praises his skills and influence on the team. The passage also mentions that Liverpool will face Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final and that if they win, Gerrard will play in his final match at Anfield before moving to LA Galaxy. The article concludes with Skrtel's belief that Liverpool has potential replacements for Gerrard and that the team will work together to fill his void.

The passage describes Jack Nicklaus, a 75-year-old golfer, who hit a hole in one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. He is considered the greatest golfer of all time and has won six Masters titles. The passage also mentions that five hole-in-ones were made during the tournament, including one by Camilo Villegas, who lost out to Kevin Streelman in a playoff.

The passage describes several tornadoes that occurred in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. The tornadoes caused damage to buildings and trees, and there were reports of wind damage and flooding in some areas. The storms are expected to continue in the Midwest and other regions.

The passage describes the case of Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy who accidentally shot and killed Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates, who was working as a reserve deputy for the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter. The judge granted Bates permission to go to the Bahamas for a family vacation, which prompted a response from the Harris family, who expressed surprise and disappointment with Bates' decision. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The passage also mentions that Bates was not qualified to be on the force and received preferential treatment because he made donations to the agency and was a friend of the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied allegations that supervisors forged Bates' records and reassigned them when they refused. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11th. He has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, which he says is a symbol of his determination to defeat Aldo. McGregor claims that Aldo lacks the same motivation to defend his title as he does to win it. The two fighters have a history of feuding, and McGregor recently grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, was criticized for skolling a beer at an Australian Rules function, which was seen as glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with drinking alcohol. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, stated that Abbott's actions set up a culture where drinking is not about socializing with friends, but about how quickly and how much one can drink. Abbott's skolling was seen as a performance and display of masculinity, which can lead people to forget their limits and engage in irresponsible drinking practices. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, stating that there was "nothing wrong" with them.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in the number of HIV cases in Scott County, which is located about 30 miles north of Louisville, Kentucky. The number of confirmed HIV cases has risen to 120, with 10 preliminary positive cases. This increase is attributed to the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana among intravenous drug users in the county. The Indiana State Department of Health has declared an epidemic in the area and expects the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The growing number of cases could put pressure on Governor Mike Pence to extend the 30-day needle exchange program that he approved on March 26. The needle exchange program has been providing clean syringes to 86 participants, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. However, the future of the Scott County program, as well as the fate of legislation that would allow needle-exchange programs in other counties, is not clear.

The passage describes a football fan who quizzes his girlfriend on her knowledge of his favorite football club, Arsenal FC. The girlfriend scores an impressive 43.5 out of 50 and is not dumped by her boyfriend. The test consists of multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and an "in your own words" section. The girlfriend scores an impressive 87% but struggles with some questions, such as naming all 11 players of the starting squad and understanding player positions. The boyfriend grades her an "A" and rewards her by not ending their relationship. The passage also mentions other reactions to the test, such as praise from football fans and criticism from those who feel the boyfriend took things too far.

The passage describes Carlos Toro, a former Medellin Cartel member who spent 27 years working as an undercover operative for the DEA in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. However, he is now facing deportation after declining health forced him to retire. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship application, and he fears for his safety if returned to Colombia. Toro's work helped prosecute drug lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega.

A 14-year-old Indian girl set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now in critical condition with 70% burns at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The accused men have been arrested. The incident has sparked protests and calls for more protection for women in India.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is looking forward to his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite having to play without Robin van Persie due to ankle trouble. Van Gaal believes that finishing in second or third place would be a good result for United, and he wants his team to move towards that target by taking all three points against City. Van Gaal acknowledges that City will provide a stern challenge, but he does not believe that he will be motivated by revenge after losing the away fixture earlier in the campaign. Luke Shaw is also ruled out due to fitness concerns.

The passage describes a protest by Arsenal and Liverpool fans at the Emirates Stadium during a Premier League match, where they left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes to protest against the rising cost of football tickets. The protest was in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, which has led to higher ticket prices. The fans hope that the image of empty seats will raise awareness of the struggles fans face to meet the rising costs of following their clubs. The protest was organized by the Black Scarf Movement, Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. The fans are calling for tangible reductions in ticket prices in line with what working-class people earn. Further protests are expected after the match.

A newborn baby with biliary atresia underwent a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister after her parents were told she needed a transplant to survive. The baby's skin turned yellow shortly after birth, prompting doctors to run tests on her liver. The condition can lead to liver failure and death if untreated. The most common treatment is the Kasai procedure, which allows bile to drain directly into the bowel. Both parents volunteered for the surgery but were told neither was a good enough candidate for a partial liver transplant. The baby's mother's twin sister was tested and told that she would give the baby the best chance of survival. The baby underwent the operation in November and has since made a good recovery.

The passage describes a football challenge between Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake against Loic Remy and Willian. The players aimed to score goals into a car from different distances, with Hazard and Ake winning the first two rounds. In the final round, Remy and Willian won, but Willian accidentally broke a wing mirror during the challenge.

The passage describes the sentencing of Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, who caused a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. During his sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal on the day of the crash. The couple, Amanda Murph and Jason Timmons, were killed instantly in the crash on December 7, 2013. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. The passage also mentions that Dellinger's wife, Deborah, described him as a man of ethics, integrity, and friendship.

The passage describes the sentencing of Lacey Spears, a woman convicted of poisoning her five-year-old son with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison, which was less than the maximum 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his hope that she would die in prison and stated that she needed to be beaten to death in prison. The judge who sentenced Spears said she suffers from a mental illness and that the crime was unfathomable in its cruelty. Prosecutors asked for the maximum sentence, saying Spears made her son ill because she had a bizarre need for attention. Spears' lawyer requested the minimum 15 years to life and blamed the hospital for negligence.

The passage describes the arrival of an improved influenza vaccination in Australia due to the emergence of two new strains of influenza that caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine includes protection against influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket, which were not covered by the previous vaccine. High-risk groups, such as the very young and very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will be able to access free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, recommends that everyone should get the modified vaccine, which also provides protection against influenza A strain H1N1. The modified vaccine is expected to be a better match for the strains circulating globally and may help prevent more deaths per capita than the previous vaccine.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism and budget cuts that could threaten the management of the historic site. The tomb was recently criticized in National Geographic magazine as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The Illinois state government is facing a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages sites including the tomb. The tomb has seen recent repairs and renovations, but the caretakers are concerned about future funding and the impact of the criticism.

The passage describes various nineties and noughties fashion trends that are making a comeback, including chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, and corsets. The passage also mentions that some of these trends, such as the wide-legged "rave" jeans made by JNCO, are considered impractical and should be left in the past.

The passage covers various trending stories, including a photo of four rainbows over New York, exotic dancers being banned in China, RDJ's comments on the Kardashians, a 102-year-old woman's prom proposal, Ewan McGregor's casting in Beauty and the Beast, Johnny Depp's appearance in Black Mass, and a military dad's creative way of announcing his wife's pregnancy.

Serena Williams won her 700th career match at the Miami Open, which led to a giant celebration cake being presented to her. Andy Murray also received a cake after his 500th career win. Williams advanced to the semi-finals with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 victory over Sabine Lisicki. She will face Simona Halep in the final after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5.

The passage describes the tragic death of Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist and advocate for women's entrepreneurship, who was shot and killed by two gunmen in Karachi, Pakistan. The shooting occurred after Mahmud led a discussion group on a controversial topic, which many wanted silenced. The passage highlights Mahmud's bravery and dedication to promoting humanism, love, and tolerance, and her efforts to create a space for open discussion and secular wisdom in Pakistan. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to speak out against violence and oppression, and her death has sparked widespread grief and gratitude for her work.

The passage describes the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Indian Kashmir, who have been denied citizenship rights and other basic rights for decades. The author discusses the history of the WPRs, their struggle for recognition, and the impact of the recent election victory of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party on their prospects for change. The passage also highlights the ongoing conflict in Kashmir and the challenges faced by the WPRs in securing their rights.

The passage discusses FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto's consideration of joining Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. Club President Naoki Ogane has claimed that Chelsea has made an offer for Muto, believed to be around £4 million. Muto is keen to join a club where he will play regularly and realize his potential. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic believes Muto could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge due to his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence. Muto is still considering a move to Chelsea and wants to join a club where he can play and develop. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has admitted that he is aware of Muto and that commercial interests do play a part in the club's transfer policy.

The passage discusses the importance of selecting the best players for the Australian national rugby team, regardless of where they play. It highlights the success of players like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who have performed well for Toulon, and argues that the same principle should apply to rugby as it does to football. The passage also criticizes England's policy of not selecting overseas players, and suggests that this policy is detrimental to the team's chances of success.

The passage describes the development of Greenstone, a small device designed to enhance wireless mesh networks created by Open Garden's FireChat app. The device acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move more easily within these networks. FireChat, which launched last year and has been downloaded over five million times, utilizes Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) to create a local network in which each phone becomes a node and data is passed between nodes. This allows users to send messages and photos even when there is no mobile or data signal. However, there are limits to how far a message can travel in this way, at around 200 feet (61 meters). Greenstone has been designed to solve this issue by acting as a booster to help messages move more easily within these networks. The device is still under development and only currently works with FireChat at a range of around 20 feet (6 meters). Messages sit on Greenstone until another FireChat comes within range, and the device has a one-year battery life and can hold up to 1,000 of the most recent messages. The passage describes a burlesque performer named Lillian Bustle who is attempting to eradicate the negative connotations associated with the word "fat" by embracing it as an honest, body-positive descriptor of her own physique. She calls herself "short" because she is 5'3" and "wife" because she is married, and insists that the word doesn't have to be used as a synonym for "ugly." The passage also notes that size discrimination in the workplace has risen 66% in the past 30 years, and that the top "magic wish" for girls aged 11 to 17 is to be thinner. However, the passage highlights the hope that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Lillian's own experience with burlesque has been empowering and body-positive, and she encourages others to find a similar "courage reference" to help them feel more secure and confident.

Theo Walcott and six Arsenal teammates were photographed for a Lanvin photoshoot, with Walcott having been on the bench for most of the season. Walcott hopes to start for Arsenal in their FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

The passage describes an upcoming auction of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, which will be held at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com on May 29th. The collection, which is estimated to be worth $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and more. Some of the individual items are expected to fetch more than $40,000. The auction is being organized by Prop Store, and the proceeds will go to Icon versus Icon.

The passage describes the tragic death of a seven-year-old British boy named Carwyn Scott-Howell in the French Alps. He was skiing with his family when he became separated from them and fell over a 164-foot drop into dense woodland. The family described him as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" child with a "handsome smile." The investigation revealed that Carwyn's mother, Cari, desperately tried to find her missing son. The family described him as an "adorable, caring person who gave so much love." The family said they had spent "the most happy ski holiday together" in the resort of Flaine in the days before the tragedy. The family remains in the Alps, and the community has rallied around them.

The passage describes the case of Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay who developed anorexia nervosa due to pressures to be a "size zero." She hid food, lied to her mother about eating, and survived on just one piece of fruit a day. Her dramatic weight loss led to her collapsing and being rushed to intensive care. She spent a week on a heart monitor and was eventually offered support from eating disorder organizations. Laura's story highlights the pressures on young girls to be thin and the serious consequences of anorexia nervosa.

The passage describes the unveiling of Liverpool's new home kit by Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet at Anfield. The kit is sponsored by New Balance, who signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal to replace Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers. The kit features a gingham design and is the first offering from New Balance. The players were greeted by enthusiastic fans, who expressed their support for the team. The passage also mentions that Sterling had previously rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer from Liverpool, but the club is confident that he will remain at the club for the upcoming season.

The largest single high-definition map of mysterious dark matter has been produced by University of Manchester researchers. The map shows clumps of mystery particles across 0.4 per cent of the sky and should allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe. The map was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device that is the primary instrument for the Dark Energy Survey (DES) led by Fermilab in the US. The survey uses the 13ft (four metres) Victor M. Blanco Telescope located at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) in Chile. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 per cent of the entire sky, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy.

Manchester United have made an official approach for Psv Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, who scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season. The Eredivisie champions have confirmed that the Red Devils have made a move over the Holland international, with United manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Van Gaal is already familiar with the qualities of Depay having named him in his 23-man World Cup squad last year as Holland finished third in Brazil. Depay is enjoying a prolific season at the Philips Stadion where he has scored an emphatic 20 goals in 26 league games so far this season. The 21-year-old took his tally to 20 on Saturday Psv Eindhoven beat Heerenveen 4-1 to win the Dutch championship on Saturday for the first time in seven seasons. Chelsea defeated Manchester City in the Youth Cup Final with a commanding 3-1 lead, thanks to goals from Tammy Abraham and Dominic Solanke. The match was played at the Academy Stadium, and the youngsters put up a strong fight. However, Chelsea's defense was solid, and they were able to hold onto their lead. The match was a showcase of young talent, with players from both teams putting in impressive performances.

Marco Rubio has stated that people are born with a sexual preference and believes that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He supports allowing state legislatures to decide on same-sex marriage, rather than having it be a federal issue. Rubio also mentioned that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staff member, even if he didn't agree with it. He believes that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman.

The passage describes Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, two intrepid cyclists who have quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and embarked on a global cycling adventure with no plans or agenda. They have covered almost 7,000 miles in 356 days, visited 16 countries, and are currently in Turkey. They have been living on less than three euros each a day, relying on free accommodation and not needing a budget for transport. Their only major expense is food, which takes up just 2.74 euros each per day of their 2.99 total outlay. They plan to continue their journey into Asia and eventually cycle all the way across the American continent.

The passage describes a couple from Texas who hired a photo booth for their 2012 wedding, but discovered that the photos included hurtful racial slurs written by the photographer. The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, filed a lawsuit against the photo booth owner, James Evans, alleging negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations and claims there is no evidence linking the company to the offensive captions. The couple is seeking an apology, not monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled for tomorrow, with a trial set for July if an agreement cannot be reached.

The passage describes the cautious approach taken by Mike Brown in recovering from his latest concussion setback. Brown remains unsure when he will return to action for his club side Harlequins. He is determined not to suffer an extended break and will not rush himself back to action ahead of time. The passage also mentions that George North has been advised by leading medics not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions, while Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier this term. The passage highlights the importance of increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion and the dangers of the long and short-term effects.

The passage discusses the decline in the frequency of sex among Britons since the emergence of the internet, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. The statistician at Cambridge University, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that smartphone use may be to blame for this decline, as it has led to a blurring of the lines between public and private life and increased competition for our time.

The passage describes the decline in popularity of Tibetan mastiffs in China due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning large dogs in certain cities. The dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in hotpots. The passage also mentions that the dogs' skin can be used for leather belts.

The passage describes a survey conducted in Paris that found that every woman surveyed had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Half of the women surveyed reported experiencing harassment before the age of 18. The survey also found that harassment can range from verbal abuse to physical assault, and that many women are afraid to use public transport due to the fear of attack. The report called for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, and emphasized the importance of women's safety and freedom of movement in public spaces.

The passage describes a competition called #everydayfix by Direct Line, where groups were asked to design products to deal with common problems. Three products were picked for a shortlist: Snooze, Forget Me Lock, and Nipper. The competition is being held on Twitter, and the product with the most retweets will go into a Kickstarter fundraising campaign and ultimately into development.

The police crime commissioner for Northumbria, Vera Baird, has been investigated by the Ministry of Justice after allocating more than £500,000 of public money to a charity of which she is the director. The charity, Victims First Northumbria, supports crime victims in her area and is led by Chief Constable Sue Sim, who is also a director of the organization. Critics have accused them of creating a conflict of interest and a "soap opera" within the force. The Home Secretary implemented a rule allowing PCCs to commission services for victims of crime, but critics argue that this should never have been done.

Three people were sent to prison and two are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Corey Campbell, 21, was the ringleader of the gang, known as the "tattoo terrorists," who believed the victim, Greg Valecce, had hurt their cat, Pebbles. The incident occurred in late March 2014, and the trio filmed the abuse. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, cornered Valecce in the basement and took turns punching, slapping, and spitting on him. Valecce suffered three broken ribs, two broken wrists, and fractured bones in his face. The incident lasted about 42 hours, and Valecce was able to escape on April 1 while the others slept and contacted police. All three were charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment, and they all pleaded guilty.
